PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes the amendment of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 to provide for a cash bidding system for the award of petroleum permits in highly prospective off-shore areas. Following an amendment passed by the Senate on 12 November, the cash bidding legislation will require re-endorsement by the Parliament two years after the date on which it commences if it is to continue in effect. The Government is re-introducing this Bill following further extensive examination of the alternatives to cash bidding and, in particular, attempts to identify suitable modifications to the traditional work program bidding system. The end result of this evaluation, reinforced by industry's response to proposed modification to the work program system, has been to confirm the Government's view that, where competition is expected to be high, the cash bidding system is the most efficient and equitable means of awarding petroleum exploration and exploitation rights.

As other countries and explorers in those countries have demonstrated, to their mutual benefit, the cash bidding system not only allows the industry to determine the amount the community should receive for the granting of these rights, but also represents a self-contained selection process. The system allows the explorer to determine and carry out an exploration strategy in the light of the commercial realities of the day, free from unnecessary government regulation. By contrast, in highly prospective areas, the present work program system, and various proposals for modification to the system that have been put forward by the industry and others, involve what I believe to be an excessive degree of regulation.

This regulation does little to encourage exploration activity. In fact, it seems to imply that industry will do nothing unless forced to by the legal requirements of the permits issued by the Government. I would have thought that industry would be keen to see the removal of this form of government regulation and its replacement with a system which enables companies to operate strictly on the basis of commercial judgments. However, as we have seen on previous occasions, industry frequently prefers to operate in the relative comfort of a government-regulated environment.

The Government has major reservations about increasing government regulation, particularly when there are better options available which would involve far less government regulation in the day to day activities of the industry. Many of these day to day decisions are best made by explorers in the light of economic and technical circumstances at the time. In many cases government involvement promotes uncertainty, delays and unnecessary conflict between government and industry. I believe that government should be setting the broad parameters in this area of off-shore petroleum activity and then letting companies get on with the job of exploration and development.

While I and other members of the Government-and this is particularly true of my colleague in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, QC-have on a number of occasions this year put on record the rationale for cash bidding, a rationale that has never seriously been challenged, I believe these arguments bear repeating now. I think that the Opposition should recognise the efficacy of the cash bidding system contained in the Bill.

The trigger for introducing the cash bidding system has been the significant shortcomings of the work program bidding system where there is high competition for exploration permits. In these circumstances, the work program system, first, encourages companies to propose substantial exploration programs that may later prove to be uneconomic either because of changes in economic conditions or a downgrading in prospectivity following initial exploration; and secondly, forces the government, where a work program becomes uneconomic, either to agree to exemptions from parts of the work program, which undermines the credibility of the system and is inequitable to unsuccessful bidders, or require the permittee to undertake the uneconomic exploration under threat of cancellation of the permit. Neither course is in the long term interest of the exploration industry. Thirdly, it requires a subjective selection of the winning bid where competition is high, as no amount of technical advice can differentiate readily between work programs of a similar character and size, nor can that advice predict whether the work program will actually be completed by the applicant; and, fourthly, it is costly and complex to administer, as work programs must be verified throughout the life of the permit in order to maintain the credibility of the system.

Recent experience in the Gippsland Basin illustrates these difficulties. Applications were invited in 1980 for three permits for highly prospective areas, attracting 29 bidders overall with more than eight for each permit. Most bidders proposed large work programs, but a whole variety of different exploration philosophies were involved, and acute difficulties were experienced in choosing between them even after careful evaluation of the technical aspects of the proposals and detailed discussions with the applicants. In the end, after all this effort, there is no evidence that the Government got it right: One permit was surrendered after only four wells were drilled from a commitment of 12 wells; another is being surrendered after only seven wells have been completed from an original program of 19 wells; and the third permittee has deferred some commitments and applied for a reduced program. There is every indication that the same circumstances may be repeated if the work program bidding system is applied to the area of highly prospective acreage in the Timor Sea region.

Following rejection of the cash bidding legislation by the Senate, the Government proposed a number of modifications to the work program bidding system aimed-to the extent that this is possible-at overcoming its major deficiencies.In summary, these proposed modifications, which reflected many of the suggestions industry made earlier in the year, would require applicants to identify minimum guaranteed `dry hole' exploration programs and separate `supplementary' work programs tied to the outcome of the initial exploration. Where a winning application cannot be determined on the basis of the minimum guaranteed `dry hole' program a number of discretionary criteria would be used to differentiate between applications. The proposed discretionary criteria would involve consideration of competing applications on the basis of the level of Australian involvement, whether new explorers are being introduced to the Australian offshore area, past performance and commitments to source goods and services in Australia, past performance and commitments to undertake research in Australia, and demonstrated willingness to explore in `frontier' areas.

While the Government believes that modifications along these lines would improve the work program system, particularly in its application to less competive areas, these modifications do, nonetheless, in several respects, lead the Government in a direction quite contrary to that which we-and, perhaps the Opposition too-would prefer. It is clear that the modified system would significantly increase Government regulation of the industry, with no certainty that this regulation would overcome the economic efficiency and equity problems.

The need for extensive discretionary criteria in the assessment of applications, a need recognised and in fact proposed by industry, is also at odds with the principles promoted by Parliament through, for example, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. In short, the inherent weakness of work program bidding systems when used in highly competitive situations cannot be satisfactorily overcome. The efforts in devising a modified system have simply reinforced the Government's views about the economic efficiency, equity and administrative simplicity arguments in support of cash bidding. Accordingly, the release of the more prospective areas in the territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands adjacent area which were identified earlier this year-the release of which has been held up first by the defeat of this Bill earlier this year in the Senate and then by the search for an adequate alternative work program system-will be made as soon as possible after this Bill receives the royal assent. What cash bidding will do is give explorers the opportunity to adopt the optimum and most economically efficient exploration philosophy based on progressive acquisition of information about the permit areas. Commercial judgments can be made about the appropriate level of exploration at any given time, without the heavy, albeit well-intentioned, hand of government regulation intruding.

When calling applications for the award of an exploration permit under the cash bidding system, the Joint Authority will specify the period within which an application must be made the availability of a renewal option for the permit, summary details of the conditions of the permit and the matters to be taken into account in selecting the winning bid. Applicants will be required to apply for a permit over all the blocks on offer for each specified area. In their applications, bidders will be required to specify the amount they are willing to pay for the award of the permit. Further, the application will be required to contain details of the technical and financial resources available to the applicant to undertake exploration in the permit, and information on any other matters that the applicant wishes to be considered. The permits will not be subject to an exploration work program commitment. A fee of $3,000, of which 90 per cent will be refunded if the application is unsuccessful, will be payable on lodging an application.

No reserve prices will be set for permit areas, but the Joint Authority will have the right to reject bids if they are considered inadequate on account of insufficient competition or if there is evidence of collusive bidding. Bids may also be rejected if the bidder is considered to lack the technical competence or financial resources necessary to undertake successfully complex off-shore exploration. This right to reject bids is available to the Joint Authority under the work program system. However, unlike the work program system, the cash bidding system requires the Joint Authority to specify these matters at the time applications are called. In this way bidders will be fully aware of all the conditions relevant to the selection of the winning bid. If, after assessment of all the bidders, only one bid remains, the permit will be offered to that consortium. If two or more bids remain, the permit will be offered to the applicant making the highest bid.

In order to provide maximum flexibility to bidders, there is no obligation on the winning bidder to accept the offer of a permit. Not only would it be impracticable to force consortia to accept offers of a permit, but in attempting to do so competition would be restricted. A similar provision also applies under the work program system. If the highest bidder rejects the offer, the permit will be offered to the next highest bidder and so on. Once a consortium has accepted an offer of a permit and paid the amount bid, the permit will be awarded to that consortium as soon as is practicable which, unless there are some unforeseen circumstances, would generally be within one month.

To ensure there is a clear incentive to undertake exploration in the permits and to discourage speculators from sterilising the acreage, only a limited renewal option will be available for cash bid permits. All cash bidding permits will be available for an initial six-year period and where the Joint Authority considers that the permit is sufficiently large, the availability of a single five-year renewal option for up to 50 per cent of the permit area will be announced at the time applications are invited for the acreage.

However, given that cash bidding permits will cover very small areas in comparison with work program bidding areas, extended periods beyond the initial six year term and one five year renewal will not be necessary to explore the areas. There are already ample opportunities for a permittee to retain tenure over a discovery even after the permit has expired. The introduction of retention leases in separate legislation earlier this year provides an additional avenue for retaining tenure over any discoveries that cannot be immediately developed.

In respect of security of tenure over a permit issued under this legislation, I emphasise that although the legislation will be in force for only two years in the first instance, there are safeguard provisions which guarantee that a permit will be able to run its full term, including renewal where relevant. Permittees will, of course, be required to meet all conditions normal for any permit such as any special environmental conditions and the compliance with the directions issued by the joint authority which deal, for example, with the manner in which activities must be undertaken. Summary details of these conditions will be made known at the time applications are called.

During the initial two-year life of this legislation, cash bidding is to be used in the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands adjacent area which is solely administered by the Commonwealth. Extension of the life of the legislation and its application to off-shore areas adjacent to the States and the Northern Territory will depend on the outcome of the review of the system's effectiveness in this two year trial period. The Government has no doubt that the cash bidding system will be a success. The legislation provides that the Joint Authority, which consists of the Commonwealth Minister and the relevant State or Northern Territory Minister, must make decisions on which areas are to be released under the cash bidding system. Not only will consultation take place through the Joint Authority process, but also the Government intends that there will be separate discussions which will take account of the sharing of revenue derived from cash bids. Accordingly, there are no revenue sharing provisions contained in this Bill. The States and the Northern Territory are already aware that cash bidding revenue sharing will be addressed in the context of discussions on sharing of resource rent tax revenue.

As I indicated earlier, I believe it is worth while to address once again the unsubstantiated claims and criticisms that have been made against cash bidding. These are that cash bidding will reduce the amount of money available for exploration, that it will increase the costs and risks of exploration, that small to medium size Australian companies will be disadvantaged and that it is inconsistent with RRT. First, I deal with the argument that cash bidding will reduce the funds available for exploration. The assumption underlying this argument is that the funds available for exploration are fixed-that the Australian exploration industry is a closed shop within which a given amount of funds circulates, without either escaping or being topped up. There is no evidence to suggest this is the case. In deciding to bid for a particular permit, a company will design an exploration program that enables it to assess properly the petroleum potential and to estimate the expected return on investment in that program. The extent to which the estimated return from the program exceeds the company's required return will determine the size of the cash bid. If no excess returns are expected, the company will not bid.

Similarly, the payment of a cash bid will not reduce activity in other exploration areas. Certainly companies may need to rearrange their investment priorities in a normal commercial decision-making manner. This however will not result in companies neglecting the evaluation of petroleum prospects which are expected to be profitable. Obviously, the most profitable prospects, which are likely to be in cash bid areas, will be explored first-but there is nothing wrong, from the point of view of the national interest or anything else, with exploration taking place in more prospective areas first. The decision to acquire a permit by way of cash bidding is essentially similar to a decision to acquire an interest in a permit by way of farm-in. When an exploration company decides to pay a premium by way of a farm-in its concern is that the permit and other permits in which the company has an interest are explored in a way which is consistent with the commercial realities of the day. Further, it is of no concern to the company what happens to the premium it has paid-whether it remains in the Australian exploration industry or not.

A clear example of the cash bidding/farm-in analogy is provided by a farm-in arrangement completed earlier this year, in which an Australian company decided within 30 days to pay tens of millions of dollars to a foreign company for the latter's interest in an attractive permit. The Australian company's exploration budget was unaffected and the foreign company has no current intention to invest the funds in exploration in Australia. Farm-ins are an essential feature of the exploration industry. There is no suggestion that they result in reduced exploration, nor can it be sustained that cash bidding will result in reduced exploration. Rather than reducing funds, there is every prospect that the net effect of the introduction of cash bidding may be to add substantially to the pool of investment funds available for exploration in the medium term. It appears that a number of overseas companies with no previous experience in Australia, who have been very reluctant hitherto to compete against those with local knowledge and experience in work program bidding, have now expressed an inclination to participate in cash bidding, where they see their lack of on-the-ground experience as no hindrance.

Secondly, I refer to the argument that cash bidding will be a disincentive to off-shore exploration because of the extra financial risk involved. Companies will take into account the expected risks and costs involved in exploring a permit when they are considering bidding for the permit, and the size of the cash bid will reflect that calculation. The cash bid in no way changes the risks or the costs involved, rather, it is the risks and costs which influence the size of the cash bid. Compared with the work program system, the cash bidding system will actually reduce the risks faced by companies. Under the cash bidding system, companies would be free to undertake the most commercially viable exploration program consistent with the prevailing economic conditions and prospectivity assessments. Under the work program system, by contrast, companies are committed to an exploration program designed up to six years in advance, and must face the considerable risk that changing circumstances will make that exploration program uneconomic.

Thirdly, there is the argument that cash bidding will discriminate against most Australian companies, which do not have access to large amounts of exploration capital. Because of the very high costs, risks and level of technical skills involved, it will always be difficult for the smaller companies to participate in off-shore exploration. Irrespective of the method of awarding permits, it will be the stronger companies which dominate off-shore exploration. It is the applicant who values the permit highest who will be prepared to bid the most under either the cash bidding or work program bidding systems. As has been the case in the past, it is very likely that consortia including Australian companies would be formed to bid for permits under the cash bidding system. Although there are no Australian equity requirements at the exploration stage, many foreign companies seek to include Australian companies in their consortia because of the 50 per cent local equity requirement should petroleum be found and developed. Under cash bidding, there is no reason whatever to anticipate a change to this practice. Permits will be awarded under the cash bidding system without prejudice to the need to meet foreign investment criteria at the development stage.

Fourthly, I refer to the argument that cash bidding is inconsistent with the RRT concept. The Government's view is that they are complementary measures which will collect for the community a share of the economic rent, or super profit, which results from the exploitation of Australia's petroleum resources. They are complementary in other ways as well. The existence of RRT, and the non-deductibility of cash bids against it, is a significant influence on the level of cash bids. Non-deductibility will mean that bids will be lower. At the same time the existence of an RRT regime in place alongside the cash bidding regime means that companies will not face the risk that in the event of a cash bid proving too low in the light of subsequent discoveries, some additional form of tax will be imposed to increase the community's take. By combining cash bidding with RRT, companies can bid with certainty as to the return the community expects, and can bid conservatively.

There is no foundation whatever for the assertion that the Government's main motive in introducing cash bidding is revenue. The primary objective is to enhance the economic efficiency and equity with which highly sought after permits are allocated, and to overcome the deficiencies I have already detailed in these and other respects in the present work program bidding system. While there is, as I have already said, a secondary revenue objective-that is, to ensure, by the combination of cash bidding and RRT, that the community receives its appropriate share of economic rent-it should be clear from any examination of our proposed cash bidding legislation that the Government is not seeking to maximise revenue from this source. If revenue was the key concern, the Government would be offering large permits with unlimited renewal opotions; it would be encouraging speculators; and it would be allowing deductability of cash bids against RRT and company tax.

I indicated during the second reading debate on the cash bidding legislation that if the cash bidding proposal was rejected, the Government would be proposing the introduction of two new imposts; signature bonuses for the award of permits in the more prospective off-shore areas, and retention lease premiums. The Minister has subsequently discussed these proposals with the industry and advises that these proposals represent a second best approach. As the Government anticipated, the industry is resisting these proposals in much the same way as it resisted cash bidding. However, the revenue shortfall created by the rejection of the cash bidding legislation, coupled with the difficult Budget deficit situation which the Government continues to face, remain important considerations. The Government has not yet finalised its consideration of the details of the signature bonus and retention lease premium measures. However, if the cash bidding legislation is passed it would not be appropriate to proceed with the signature bonus proposal and not be necessary to proceed with the retention lease premium proposal. No realistic estimate is possible of the amount of revenue that might be raised by the award of permits under the cash bidding system. It will depend on the number of areas released during each financial year and industry's appraisal and response to these releases.

This Bill also proposes the amendment of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Exploration Permit Fees) Act 1967 to exempt permits awarded under the cash bidding system from annual fees. Taking into account the reduction in administrative work and the small size of cash bid permits, it is not sensible to charge fees which might amount to no more than $400 per year. The amendments proposed in this Bill are essential to allow the introduction of an equitable, effective and administratively efficient system of awarding petroleum exploration permits in the more prospective off-shore areas.

Before I intone the ritual words of committal, I should explain that unfortunately the explanatory memorandum is now being amended to take account of changes in the Senate and will be made available to honourable members at the first possible opportunity. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Braithwaite) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL REFORM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the House concurs in the resolution transmitted in message No. 162 of the Senate relating to the resolution of appointment of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, and
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution.

Mr Speaker, I think all honourable members are aware of the success of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Because other matters may come before the Parliament, such as is the case with the Macklin Bill, it is felt that, rather than try to sort them out and deal with them in the parliamentary sense in the first instance, it would be better for the Committee, which has access to constitutional and electoral experts who can appear before it and give it advice on matters such as this, to do so, and that we ought to extend the terms of reference of the Committee so that other matters that may be sought to be referred to the Committee from time to time by either House can be referred.

The Committee has done an outstanding job since it was established under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) in May 1983. It still has a lot of work before it. An examination of the new laws as they applied to the 1984 elections will be coming before the Parliament very shortly. I know that a number of recommendations from the Australian Electoral Commission will be made for the Joint Committee to look at.

I think the Parliament will be requesting the Committee continuously to look at these sorts of things. I have therefore moved that we extend this reference so that other matters that can be decided on from either House from time to time can be referred to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition recognises the need to amend the terms of reference to this Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. However, we are concerned at the potential consequences of this amendment, which may allow some people to indulge in a witch hunt for party political purposes and may allow the Government to embark upon the implementation of some points within an agenda. We note the position in the Senate, with a member of that House proposing to introduce a private member's Bill to examine the question of one vote one value in Australia. I think it is apparent to every member of this House who knows anything about the Australian Constitution that it prohibits the notion of one vote one value. Unless this Government is proposing to amend the Australian Constitution fundamentally, to withdraw the guarantee given to Tasmania and some of the less populous States as to their representation in this place and in the Senate, the concept of one vote one value just does not fit into the Australian Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: I think perhaps the best place to have that sort of debate is in the Committee where, as the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has said, there is access to expert legal advice. To understand the point I make those members of the Senate who have not read the Constitution and who have not been able to calculate the numbers of people who live and vote in the less populous States relative to the more populous States need give only some consideration to the vote for the Senate in, say, Tasmania, where each senator attracts about 32,000 votes, whereas a senator in New South Wales requires about 381,000 votes to be elected. That obviously is not one vote one value. If we address the question of representation in this place, the same thing applies. There is a guarantee of five seats to Tasmania. The enrolment in those five seats is considerably less than the enrolment in seats in the other States of Australia, and that makes a nonsense of one vote one value. As the Government has the numbers on this Committee and as the present Chairman has said on occasions, `We will try to keep things affable and amiable, but when it comes to the crunch we will use our numbers to achieve what we want', there is some doubt as to whether the Government is at present adopting a non-party political approach to electoral reform and review of the electoral laws in Australia.

I am reminded of the events preceding the last general election and the comments made by the Minister in the evening, just as the polls closed. Madam Deputy Speaker, you will remember that as a result of the work of the previous Select Committee certain changes were made to the electoral laws of Australia, one of which affected the voting mechanism and procedures for the Senate. The Government at the time, this Government, decided there would be changes to the voting procedures for the Senate. Recognising that it was a major change and that perhaps Australians would be unfamiliar with that change, and because it would represent a fundamentally different approach to the voting mechanism which had been used in this country almost since Federation, it decided there was a need for an advertising campaign to make sure that everybody understood how to vote.

I think the Minister said, at about five past six that Saturday evening: `It was a great advertising campaign. I think they did a great job and we are very pleased with it'. At about 10 past nine on Sunday morning, when the magnitude of the informal vote was apparent to everybody, I think he changed his mind. I wonder whether he now thinks we got value for our some $2m. I am also reminded of the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on that morning. He actually suggested that the people who supported his Party, the Australian Labor Party, were perhaps less capable of casting a formal vote than other people. I am amazed. I wonder whether, having suffered that sort of comment, they will vote for him and his Party again at the next election.

Notwithstanding that, I recognise the need, as does the Opposition, for a continuing review of electoral laws in Australia. We sincerely hope that the Government does not intend to use its numbers on this Committee to force through some form of hidden agenda it may have to introduce some form of optional preferential voting. If the Government is going to move towards optional preferential voting on the basis that no person in Australia should be forced to vote for a candidate he does not support, perhaps it will seek to be consistent and extend that logic to its conclusion, which is that no person in Australia should be forced to vote. If one should not be forced to vote for a candidate one does not support-which is the Government's argument in relation to compulsory exhaustive preferential voting-the logic of course is that one should not be forced to vote at all. Given the attitude expressed by Labor governments in New South Wales in relation to this question, I wonder whether we have any hope of seeing a more equitable and fairer approach by this Government if it should choose to move on the issue of optional preferential voting. Of course, the Government would choose to do so only for its own party political advantage, recognising the political structure of the Opposition and the coalition between the Liberal Party and the National Party in Australia.

It concerns me also that from time to time electoral reform is used as an excuse to grandstand in this place. Yesterday we saw members of the Government seek to debate a matter of public importance. Honourable members opposite described the recent Queensland electoral redistribution as a public outrage. They pretended that this place had the authority to discuss the responsibilities of a sovereign government of this country. Of course, as the Labor Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) said, electoral redistribution in Queensland is of no concern to this Parliament and to this Government. I hope that the Government will resist the temptation to exploit the advantage of its numbers on this Committee and in this place for party political purposes. I hope also that the Government will use its numbers to stop any other member of this Parliament seeking to grandstand and score cheap political points in relation to electoral reform and to indulge in some sort of witch hunt or bashing of one party or another-particularly if it has no representation on the Committee and is unable to answer the charges that some people would lay against it. We recognise that this amendment to the terms of reference of the Electoral Reform Committee will give it more flexibility. We hope it is the Government's intention to use the terms in an honourable fashion for the true purpose of improving the electoral system of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) in relation to the acceptance of the amendment to the proposed new terms of reference of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I think the amendment gives more flexibility to the terms of reference of the Committee. I think it is sensible to allow, if one likes, extraneous suggestions, which would otherwise be debated in the Parliament, not to take up the time of the Parliament, initially at least, to receive a close scrutiny by the Committee which would allow if necessary a more informed debate later on in the Parliament. Therefore, I think it is wise to give the Joint Select Committee that extra flexibility. I think it will make the workings of the Committee sound. Also, it will enable the Committee to look at a wider range of suggestions than is presently the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter which I would like to bring to the Parliament's attention-it is not often that the House of Representatives has some difference with the Senate-relates to the Senate Hansard of 13 November. I was concerned to read on page 2040 of that Hansard that the motion for the resolution of appointment for the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform moved by Senator Gareth Evans and agreed to concluded with paragraph (1) (iii). The Hansard report then moved to the reference to the Committee of Privileges of the detention of a senator. I am not sure whether the fact that the resolution of appointment, which was agreed to, does not appear to have been accurately reported in the Senate Hansard has any effect on its validity. In fact, about half of the actual resolution, agreed to by the Senate, is missing from the Hansard report.

The comments in relation to other matters made by my colleague, the honourable member for Richmond, do need a little underlining as well. It is obvious that the Government is seeking to move towards an optional preferential voting system. It perceives that system to be in the electoral interests of its Party to remain in Government. I reiterate the comment made by my colleague that if that is the intention of the Government, I hope that the logical conclusion will be pursued which would allow people to have a choice whether they vote. I know that under the present system a person is not forced to vote, but is forced to attend a polling place. To all intents and purposes, the vast majority of the voting public of Australia think that they are actually compelled to vote. I hope that the logical conclusion is pursued because it does seem to me to follow that if the argument is that a person should not be forced to vote for somebody that he does not wish to vote for, he should not be forced to vote at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have a couple of things to say in response to the matters that have been raised, firstly, about the question of optional preferential voting. This matter has been discussed in the Australian Labor Party for a long time. It is just part of the cut and thrust of debate which takes place in this country as to the various policies of the Party. It is just the same as the National Party of Australia wanting weighted electorates so that the country elec- torates are much smaller than the city electorates, as was the position for a long period under conservative governments. I am not sure that the record is correct, but I understand that if we had had one vote one value in Australia in 1954, 1961, 1969 and 1980, we could have quite easily had very different governments to the governments that we had. We only had conservative goverments re-elected on those occasions because the voting system was weighted to give advantages to the conservative governments.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the national debate on this matter, the Australian Democrats have said that they do not support optional preferential voting for their very own subjective reasons-that is, that their influence in being able to allocate preferences would disappear for the House of Representatives. Because the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform is made up of all the parties, I suspect it will go on debating these matters.

As for compulsory voting, it may be true that there is an argument for saying that in a democracy people should go and vote if they want to and they should not be compelled to vote. There is a great difficulty about that. If one analyses what is occurring and what has grown up in recent years, one will find a never-ending sequence of surveys of voter intentions have been carried out. They are done not only at election time now; they are done continuously. So we are all jumping up and down every Wednesday when the Bulletin appears to see what is going to happen 2 1/2 years off. It has reached a rather ridiculous stage in Australia, as it has in other countries. Honourable members might have noticed that in other countries and other democracies because the surveys have shown that one party is overwhelmingly going to win the election a lot of its supporters stay at home. The results have not turned out the way the surveys have predicted. So influences on what people are going to do and whether in fact they are going to go and vote can again be changed by the information which comes out prior to an election. Those sorts of matters ought to be looked at too.

I think that the Committee is obviously a very constructive way in which to do all the preliminary work before it hits the floor of parliament. I do not think we are going to change too many views of the parties. They have been around too long and their views are too well entrenched. I do know that if we were to do to the national electoral boundaries what the National Party is doing in Queensland to its boundaries, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) who spoke representing the National Party would be jumping up and down in here saying what a group of blighters we were for having gerrymandered the Federal system. There is no intention to do that here. I hope that the benefits of what we have done in giving Australia the great electoral laws of 1983-changes which the Hawke Labor Government brought in-will be with us forever. I think it is a very good idea for the Committee to look at all these matters when they are raised because the expectation outside is a rather simple one. Some people outside say: `Why don't you pass the Macklin Bill, because that means one vote one value for all the parliaments throughout Australia?'. Anyone who has spent a bit of time in Parliament knows that it is not quite so simple. People outside may have a different view of what are the powers of the Parliament vis-a-vis ideas put forward, whether they be in the form of a private member's Bill or a motion or an idea or a suggestion brought up in debate. Using the filter, if I can use that term, of a parliamentary committee before the matters are brought here is an excellent way of dealing with these matters.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN TRADE COMMISSION BILL 1985 [No. 2][COGNATE BILL:AUSTRALIAN TRADE COMMISSION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985 [No. 2]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Mr Dawkins:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill cognately with the Australian Trade Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1985. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Australian Trade Commission Bill 1985 and the cognate Bill, we must view them from the point of view that they represent the Hawke Labor Government's next step in the nationalisation of Australia's trade through politicisation, regulation and now legislation. I will give an indication of the heavy hand of that regulation and politicisaiton. We have a wages system and a prices and incomes accord in which the dictates are heavily regulated in favour of the Government. High interest rates caused by devaluation, which is another deliberate Government policy, are causing fuel price hikes. Tariff protection does nothing to improve trading. As well, this Government is reliant on deficit funding, and we have trade sanctions in quite a few areas. The Government has a policy of high taxation. The coal levy, introduced back in 1974, is still with us and is still collecting $70m in 1985-86 from a charge on the Utah company. I will say more about these points later on. I point out that there is very heavy regulation in the Government's attitude to trade. On the issue of politicisation, I must say that the morale of the staff of the Department of Trade must have sunk to an all-time low following the political appointment of David Combe to the Vancouver post to pay off a political debt. If the Government views that action in connection with what is proposed here it will see the contradiction that is there.

SPEECH.PARA: One cannot speak on a Bill such as this without referring to the recent trade results for the month of October. I say in all sincerity that, although some people believe there is joy for the Opposition in these figures, there is no joy for anyone in these figures. Further, there will be no joy unless we take action to turn that situation around. It is a very sorry situation, dealing with a matter such as the success of trade, on which every Australian's standard of living depends, when it is implied that there is joy for anyone in the figures released. There is no joy for the Government and less for the traders. There is little hope in the short term, despite the suggested J curve effect. There will be no hope in the longer term unless we address ourselves to the problems that relate to trade and which are certainly not covered by this Bill.

As to the balance of trade, the recent figure of $1.6 billion is an all-time record for a month. That figure relates to the combined trade deficit and net invisible deficit. Over the three years from 1982-83 to 1984-85, and including the October figures of $5 billion, the accumulated current account deficit is $29 billion. This should be a source of grave concern to many Australians. It is for this reason that we say that the Bill is a contradiction in many ways.

It contradicts the political appointment of David Combe. It contradicts the export market development grants reduction which was passed by this House recently. The Confederation of Australian Industry has indicated on many occasions its objection to that and others have objected to the transfer of the Export Grants Development Board to the new Australian Trade Commission. Answers have to be given to the many questions about the quickening of the grant payments and whether the expected backlog of $73m at the end of this year will be overcome by the transfer of the Board to the Commission. As I say, there are grave doubts about that.

The Bill does not address itself to the major problems facing trade. Something has to be done, quite apart from a commitment to the monetary system, to bring the system under control. Other controls are vital. The Bill is not a short term remedy. It is something that has to be put into place and the appointments have to be made. If any quick reaction is contemplated by the interim board, I do not believe that the Bill will find it. All this is happening while the Australian economy is still on its downhill slide.

The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, as part of a larger organisation, may not be as efficient as it has been in the past. It is suggested, again, that it could be cumbersome and less responsive and responsible to the tasks it currently undertakes. In that respect, it is a standing joke among Australian exporters that the Japanese have delivered before EFIC has even considered a proposal. I am saying that we require instant responses, but the Bill does not address itself to that.

The argument in connection with the Bill is that it consolidates into one statutory authority three others that have stood in its place; it absorbs them. It must be pointed out to the Parliament that that statutory authority is being given a greatly expanded power, a power beyond what the other three bodies had. I return to the proposition that it is against the philosophy of the Opposition to create powers outside the scrutiny of the Parliament. I refer to our opposition to the extended powers for the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation with respect to trading overseas and the powers of the industrial health authority as examples of the Opposition's philosophy in this respect. The whole Bill is based on a matter of trust. It will not be of any surprise to the Government to learn that the Opposition is not likely to be trusting in the manner in which the Bill and the Commission will be implemented because in that matter of trust the Government has a record of broken promises over the last three years and its economic performance, which has been excused to this date, has been inadequate.

The questions I ask of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) are: Why should the Opposition, or the traders who will be affected by the Bill by way of this new authority, expect a transfer of staff to improve morale within the Department? I understand that morale is not high. Will the expanded powers that are talked about still be maintained under parliamentary scrutiny? I believe that is not the case. Regarding the aspect of fee for service, can we expect more utilisation of the trade service by people overseas if they have to pay a fee for a commercial service? Does the Minister expect us to believe the exemption from taxation will be more likely to orientate the Commission commercially to a private practice situation? Clause 8 of the Bill provides that one of the functions of the Commission will be to facilitate and encourage trade. Will this prevent competition with traders, as we have already seen with respect to the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation? Regarding the forming of partnerships, companies and consortiums, does this mean that there will be a real interface with private business or will a predominant power be exercised under the functions clause so that it will actually take over the trading section? These are all exceptions that we are asked to carry on trust. Frankly, I do not believe that this will be the case.

It has been said that the overseas representatives of the Australian Government have an important role in government to government negotiations regarding trade agreements. We do not disagree with that, but we cannot see how it cannot be done under the present structure. Also, we have to ask whether promoting Australia's exports, arranging trade introductions, et cetera, is actually a government role. If the potential commercial benefits are sufficient traders will set up and fund such operations themselves, without the help of the Government. They will do it through the auspices of committees, such as the various business sub-committees or branches of co-operative industry groups. Also, industry associations or private agents could organise themselves to perform this role-on a fee for service basis if required-on a purely private enterprise basis. One great criterion which this Government has said is a hallmark of its economic policy is allowing foreign banks into Australia. Surely it will now become part of their accounting and information services, which are spread right across the country, to deliver this type of information into the hands of a customer who asks for it. We see this as a difficult situation.

Let me go back to considering the Department of Trade itself. I understand that recently an address was given by Bob Coombs of the Cattle Council of Australia to staff within Foreign Affairs, in which he suggested that a greater role had to be played by one department or another, or that there had to be an interlocking of the departments, so that interdepartmental frictions do not exist within the service overseas. A suggestion was floated by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) that perhaps the diplomatic and trade aspects of our representations overseas should be amalgamated, yet this legislation goes no way whatsoever towards correcting the existing situation. All we can say is that, on the implementation of this legislation, when the Commission is formed, it will still lack direction. No direction whatsoever is given to the Commission. This legislation has been described as rearranging the chairs on the Titanic; it does nothing to change the downward plunge. It is still heading in the same direction.

Under the separation of powers by the Commission, the Minister could deny responsibility for anything that happens in trade. The last thing that we want in this country today is ministerial abrogations of that responsibility. Will the Minister for Trade do a Pontius Pilate-which is what we have had with all other Ministers who have responded to problems within the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-and say: `It is not our problem; it is the commissioners' problem'? Or will we have a response from the Government similar to the one we had in the case of Australia Post, where the Government said: `We cannot get them to deliver mail. It is up to the commissioners'? Trans Australia Airlines, Qantas Airways Limited, Telecom Australia and a whole host of other authorities have separate power without ministerial authority over them. I believe that this Commission will become just another one. We are just building another structure. This legislation does nothing to correct the present problem of inter-departmental jealousies. In fact, one might be cynical enough to say that it is a further step towards a socialist goal of nationalisation of our trade.

The Opposition fears in all this that the legislation is actually a camouflage for the Government's failure on the economic front and that the Government intends to rely on the Commission as its flagship in trade. But it has not given that flagship any engine and it has not plotted any course for it. I believe that we have justifiable concerns in this regard.

Let me come back to clause 77 of this legislation to establish how commercial this Commission will be. Clause 77 states that the Commission has to take account of contingent liability and, in that regard, it mentions only the aspect of depreciation. If this were a purely commercial enterprise it would be asked to account, through the uniform corporations Act, to state all liabilities. As this Commission will operate on a fee for service basis, how can a proper fee be established when other major contingent liabilities are not also to be recognised and transferred?

In the transfer of staff from the trade service to the Commission, will account be taken of long service leave, annual leave, holiday pay, sick pay, superannuation and retirement benefits that have been accrued? All of those benefits to staff will require some commitment from and place a contingent liability on the Authority. In a proper commercial sense, those costs should be included in the fee for service figure and not a cash basis. Other corporations are asked to do this. I believe that the Australian National is moving in that direction. I put a question on notice on this matter to all Ministers. The reply that I received from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) gave me no answers. I shall deal with that matter a little more in the Committee stage. So there is no commercial basis on which the Authority can start.

I appreciate the Minister's rather frank assessment of the trade situation. That is important, because we cannot address the problems as we see them unless we have an understanding of that situation. I suggest that all honourable members have a look at that part of the Minister's second reading speech which gives the recital on Australia's trading performance ranking, which has fallen, I believe from eighth to twenty-second in the last 30 years. This has accelerated within more recent years. The fact that we are actually losing markets overseas and are not maintaining them must be a serious consideration in addressing the problem. The Minister has recognised that our trading performance has been affected by a general weakening in our current account. I have already indicated that in the last three years and four months the current account deficit amounted to $29 billion. This was not all borne by the Government; there would have been some overseas contractual debt borne by the private sector. This is a matter for serious consideration. As I said, the Minister addressed this question honestly in his 13 May statement and in his second reading speech. While the Minister came up with some conclusions, basically, he excused the Government's performance for the wrong reasons.

I turn to the end of the second reading speech, where the Minister maintains that the growth of the economy of Australia, other aspects and even, in fact, the depreciation of the dollar had some influence on trade, but these claims are not substantiated. The Minister also mentions that the prices and incomes accord has been the hallmark of the economic policy of this Government and how successful it has been, particularly with regard to the growth in jobs. I would like to have an account of that growth in jobs showing the growth in the Australian Public Service, the State Public Service and through the community employment programs and the number employed by the Australian manufacturing sector just to indicate how powerful the employment recovery has been. I shall say something about that later. The Government has given excuses; they have been the wrong reasons.

We must actually gauge the results of the Government's economic performance as it affects trade. I mentioned at the beginning of my speech that the regulation of the economy has had the effect of nationalising trade in Australia. We cannot just say that this Bill will correct all the ills. It has to be recognised, and I believe that the Minister recognises, that there are external pressures. Perhaps the Bill can correct some of those pressures, but the internal pressures on trade have not been addressed. Controlling that problem is very much in the hands of the Government.

I mention tariffs. In the Budget for 1985-86 there is a revenue commitment of $3.2 billion. The share of sales tax has to be added to that figure. The imposition of sales tax is actually a tariff. It is a major mechanism which has been built into Federal revenues for quite a few years. This has been the practice, to such an extent that it is a disincentive which prevents governments from looking positively at changes in the present tariff situation. Obviously, the tariff protections that were effective in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s in order to build up Australian internal industry are not sufficient for the 1980s. I am heartened by the fact that a recent report of the Industries Assistance Commission suggested that it would look on a rolling basis at the effects of subsidies on the economy of Australia. I mention also what the wheat growers have said in connection with the general tariffs and import quotas. The Australian of 18 October stated:
. . . general tariffs and import quotas applying to secondary industry have cut 17 per cent from the total value of agricultural commodities produced.
This reduction represents a cost of $1.5 billion a year to the farming sector or about $9,000 per farm . . .

So the costs of these tariffs are being highlighted all the time, as are the other protection mechanisms we have in Australia. That is one area to which the Government could address itself. It is right in its corner. The findings of the Industries Assistance Commission report on these subsidies-I think one would find the same in regard to tariffs-would be similar to those of the research and development survey recently taken. That survey found that 75 per cent of the applicants for grants could have survived without the assistance of those grants. The tariff situation is keeping some inefficient industries inefficient.

I turn now to interest charges. Interest rates are very much a product of the Government's present philosophy. The present high interest rates are a deliberate policy to hold up the devaluing dollar. When the present Labor Government came to office it floated the Australian dollar, giving us a fluctuating exchange rate. I suggest that because of the mechanisms the Government is adopting as far as interest charges are concerned, the Australian dollar is not a floating dollar. It is being shored up to an unrealistically high level just because of the Government's interest rates policy. We have to consider the present situation as being a result of one of the Government's policies.

The devaluation of the dollar has been heralded by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) as being of some assistance to Australian traders. I again instance the comparison in relation to our devaluation as shown in the Australian on 5 November: Whilst we have devalued our currency against the Japanese yen and the European currencies by up to one-third, our performance is reflected worst in the position of the New Zealand dollar, against which our currency has devalued by 33 per cent within 10 months. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has completely vindicated his policies. That vindication is probably based on the assessment given to the OECD representative by the Department of the Treasury on a visit he made of two or three days in this country. I suggest that the performance of our dollar and our economy is being assessed daily in the market exchanges, commodity exchanges and stock markets right around the world. If the devaluation of our dollar reflects that assessment, I do not know how the Treasurer can come into this House, praise himself and indulge in self-adulation saying that type of thing.

In respect of interest rates, I indicate the benefit our competitors enjoy in overseas markets that are not enjoyed by manufacturers in Australia. Again, I take the markets that are our strongest competitors: The European Economic Community, the United States of America and Japan. When I obtained these figures the real interest rate in France was 5.8 per cent; in West Germany, 5.3 per cent; in the United States 8.9 per cent-that was the figure when I was there last month-in Japan 7 per cent. Australia's interest rate at the time I took these comparisons was 18.5 per cent. I believe that the prime rate is now 19 to 19.5 per cent.

It is very important that we compare the rate of inflation in those countries with our own. In the same order, the inflation rate in France was 4.5 per cent; in West Germany, 2.3 per cent; in the United States, 3.5 per cent and in Japan 2 per cent. The Australian rate was 8 per cent. The real interest rate against which we must compete against our competitors overseas was almost double that of our major competitors. This is another area in which the Government is responsible.

While there have been some benefits of the devaluation of the dollar for our overseas trade, they have been offset to a large extent by the extra cost of imports and the fact that tariffs have been allowed to remain as they are, interest rates have gone up by at least 4 per cent to 5 per cent and there have been higher fuel costs. So, devaluation is not a highmark of this Government's performance. Devaluation has meant for every Australian a decline in the standard of living.

I turn to sanctions on the export of uranium, another Government policy. We have the ridiculous situation whereby, although uranium products could earn us precious dollars on the export market, we have cut their export. However, worse still I understand that on the Budget figures that we are paying $4m in compensation to companies not permitted to export. It is a ridiculous policy to declare some uranium good and some bad. That is one sanction that is affecting our overseas trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could export drugs, too, if you wanted to.
—The honourable member interjects as though dragging down the trade figures, the Australian economy and the standard of living of every Australian to his level were a normal philosophy.
—What about Afghanistan?

—The trade sanctions against Afghanistan proved to be a disaster. It was a political exercise chased by an economic remedy. It did not work in Afghanistan and I believe that I can speak for the Opposition when I say that it will not work in South Africa.
—You did Afghanistan.

—I know, and I am admitting that it was a disaster, as was the boycott of the Moscow Olympics. I am prepared to give honourable members opposite credit when it is due and to take blame. Let us also look at the deficit. Another deliberate policy of this Government has been to hold up the deficit in order to maintain expenditure. In 1984 there was a deficit of $7.9 billion. In 1985 it was $6.7 billion. The budgeted figure for this year's expected deficit-it will go beyond this figure-is $4.9 billion. Within those years the total deficit of $19.6 billion has now generated an interest commitment of $6.7 billion. It is the third largest component of the Budget-higher than health, defence and education. So in the competition for funds to balance the Government's deficit there has been an increase in overseas debt. There is an increase in that debt every time there is a devaluation and the effect on invisibles as indicated in the report I mentioned previously.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer also to taxation and the forthcoming tax package. Already we are all getting letters from major traders around Australia which indicate that they will be further penalised and will lack competitiveness on overseas markets. In fact, some traders have suggested that the tax package will jeopardise not only their future development and employment potential but also the markets they already have. A company such as Utah is already paying $70m in export coal levies and is now to be burdened with the forthcoming tax package. I have seen some figures in regard to what the costs of the tax package will mean for the rural, business and export sectors of Australia. The cost is said to be another $793m for 1986-87 and $1.2 billion for 1977-78. The tax package is another handicap deliberately brought in by this Government. The Government may say that the tax has to be high. I refer the Minister to a comparison by the World Bank of low taxing and high taxing nations. It suggests that low taxing nations have been able to increase their exports and labour productivity well in excess of countries which rely on high taxation. If the Government wants an answer to our diminishing export performance, it should look at its tax rates and the package presently before us. These are areas in which the Government can react and do so very quickly.

I refer to the regulated wages system which operates under the prices and incomes accord. If the dollar devaluated even further in the last three weeks is was because of the 3.8 per cent national wage increase, its effect on our economy and what it will do right down the line to our exports. We have been judged on that decision. It is irresponsible of the Government not to recognise the error and try to do something about it. This Government has displayed an apparent neglect in bringing to heel the Australian Council of Trade Unions over indexation, over the effect of the Mudginberri dispute on our export trade and in so many other ways. We could begin recovery in the export trade by making sure that the prices and incomes accord is renegotiated to take account of the effect of the devaluation of the dollar. More particularly, we should make sure that increases in wages are indexed to productivity. If one looks at productivity during the slump over many years one sees that under the building industry award for 40 hours of work a week, the employer pays 1.9 weeks wages with all costs accumulated. Our whole internal situation is affecting our trade overseas.

Already this legislation will be subject to at least 15 amendments, which means that it is not a perfect Bill. It does not really apply itself to commercial accounting principles and it is defective in many other ways. If we have a chance during the Committee stage, we will speak on those things. The Opposition believes that the Australian Trade Commission is just another statutory authority with increased powers and that it is taking those powers away from the Government. We oppose the legislation in that respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the remarks of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and I will comment shortly on some of the points he raised. However, I think it is important that we should come back to the purpose of this morning's exercise, and that is discussion of the Australian Trade Commission Bill which establishes the Australian Trade Commission. I believe that it is incumbent upon us to recognise that the Commission represents a good deal more than simply administrative streamlining by the Government of a number of functions that exist under different groups at present. The Australian Trade Commission, as a body corporate, will have sufficient flexibility and independence of management to respond quickly to changes in international market conditions. It will also be a source of valuable advice for the Government and provide an early warning mechanism on international changes and trends affecting Australia's trade. Finally, it will bring new initiatives to the export community because it will, in time, offer new services and a more effective and efficient means of export promotion in our overseas markets.

SPEECH.PARA: This is rather significant because for too long now-the Government has certainly not walked away from recognition of this fact-Australia's trade competitiveness has not been good. Through the establishment of an organisation which will bring about a more co-ordinated approach to international trade by offering incentives, by helping trade promotion in advertising and so on, this will greatly improve Australia's position. As I said, this Government has not walked away from the fact of our present poor trade situation. In fact, the honourable member for Dawson referred to this by saying that the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), in his statement to the House on 13 May, had given a very honest assessment of the problems associated with this position. The Government recognises that, but it intends to do something about it and this Bill is one of the major steps that will improve the situation.

Quite frankly, there have been a number of major causes of the change in our competitive position. We have been downgraded; we have slipped from eighth to twenty-fourth in our trading position and we should be starting to reverse that situation. The lack of export orientation in our manfacturing industry presents fundamental problems for the Government in formulating and pursuing its trading policies. It is imperative for us to create conditions which will encourage improved export performance in the fastest growing areas of world trade, namely, manufactures and services. The Government recognises that and has put in place a number of measures that will support that. I refer specifically to the steel industry plan, and I quote from a statement made by the Minister on 13 May:

The Government has also put into place a range of structural adjustment measures designed to assist and rejuvenate Australian industry. Special plans have been negotiated between government, business and unions in the steel and motor vehicle industries. The plans offer incentives for improved efficiency and modernisation of plant. They allow for a growing element of competition from imports, thereby imposing a discipline on domestic industries to match the performance of efficient producers in other countries.
It is important to stop and look at the position. Through the steel industry plan this Government has negotiated, we have clearly seen a turn-around in that industry, particularly in the Illawarra.

TALK.START.PARA: —The great Illawarra.

—Yes, the great Illawarra. It is also incumbent on me to pick up another point which was raised by the honourable member for Dawson, and that is the relationship between the manufacturing sector, or the business community and the Government. He certainly indicated that this Government had involved itself in the accord, and we believe that that will be one of the cornerstones of industrial policy in this country for some time to come. He also said that there was something inherently wrong with government taking a role that more properly belonged to private industry. That is a load of nonsense. For example, in the case of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (Steel) that company's performance in the overseas trade sector in the past has been poor and now it has done something about it. As part of the steel plan, BHP has now developed a steel manufacturers export project which provides Australian manufacturers with both incentive and opportunity to develop or expand export markets in two specific ways: Firstly, through the more traditional method of request to divisional sales managers in each State for flexibility of supply packages; and secondly, via the auspices of BHP's trading services division representation can be provided on an agency basis or as a principal.

SPEECH.PARA: The project offers benefits to the Australian community in a number of ways. First, it gives rebate incentives on steel purchased for export products; and secondly, it provides marketing services and transport assistance through the trading services division to which I referred a short time ago. Obviously this has important benefits for an area such as Wollongong. Jobs are created because our export potentials have improved. We have incentives for other business to expand in the Illawarra area, and there is an overall lifting of both the regional and national economies. This is a further example of the Government working hand in hand with major business to do something about our trading position. Quite clearly, it demonstrates a commitment by members on this side of the House to enter into the spirit of economic reconstruction in areas that have been ravaged by the effects of the depression created by those opposite, and to do something about it.

I refer also to the growth in trade that this Government is looking to, specifically in the Pacific rim. Traditionally our economic base has been dependent on the rural sector and, again, we have seen a downturn in that sector in recent times. We also looked to overseas markets in places such as Europe. The time has come-and this Government recognises it-to look more and more to the Pacific rim area. In recent weeks, albeit for a very short time, I had the opportunity to discuss this very matter with our trade commissioners in San Francisco.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very good discussions they were, too.

—Yes, they were very deep and meaningful discussions. Quite clearly, there is a concern in California and the western States of the United States that there is a clear trading relationship that can prosper between the Pacific rim countries, including Australia. A number of statistics can be provided. This is the most dynamic area and the Government has recognised that. It has done so by developing a number of market activities-the China action plan, the North American special exercise, the Japan market strategy, and so on. It is also looking at traditional markets such as the Middle East. All these strategies are aimed at improving our economic performance in international trade.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn quickly in the time left to me to some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Dawson. He talked about Australia's trade position and claimed that our performance, as shown in the export-import and trade announcements on the current account for October, reflected badly on the Government's performance in this area. That is absolute nonsense. After those announcements were made we saw the typical shock-horror headlines that some of the newspapers inflict upon the people of Australia-headlines such as `Crisis of confidence grips the nation'. This came from John Short writing in the Australian on 13 November. `Crisis of confidence grips the nation'-what a load of rubbish! What absolute nonsense! He went on to say that things were really crook because of the balance of trade and current account and totally misread the situation.

For 2 1/2 years this Government has been putting in place economic policies that have seen this economy turn round. We have been right on every occasion. It is about time that honourable members opposite and others in the community-those in the business community and journalists reporting the performance of this Government-recognised just how well the Government has done. The deterioration in the balance of payments can largely be explained by seasonal factors. One cannot get away from that. In adjusted terms imports actually fell by 10 per cent, and after adjustment the deficit remains roughly at the September level. The improvement will come, as the Minister for Trade and as the Treasurer, Mr Keating, have said, as a result of the devaluation in the second half of the financial year. The Treasurer has been right in everything he has said. To take, on the other hand, a view put on the same matter by that respected economics writer in the Sydney Morning Herald, Ross Gittins, one saw shock horror headlines in the Australian, but the headline in the Sydney Morning Herald was `No cause for worry-yet'. Mr Gittins wrote:
There is nothing particularly worrying about the overseas trade figures released yesterday, but there is no point in trying to tell the financial markets that.
He went on in that article:
So when you allow for these seasonal factors, the figures show no worsening in Australia's basic trade position during the month . . .
But the Government's Budget forecasts are based on the expectation that imports will only begin to slow significantly in the second half of this financial year . . .

So he recognises the thrust of Government policy and is able to see quite clearly that our policies will work and that the economy will respond. Mention has been made of the floating dollar. Frankly, this dollar of ours has been going up and down like the proverbial bride's nightie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fiddler's elbow, please!

—Very well, fiddler's elbow. I defer to my colleague from Throsby. But, frankly, the Government is totally in control of all aspects of the economic reconstruction of this country. Let us not lose sight of that fact because it is the case. There has been record growth. The subject of morale in the Department of Trade has also been mentioned. I assure the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, who is at the table, that there is no loss of morale in the Department of Trade, particularly in the Wollongong area where the regional manager, Mr Graham Jackson, is doing a splendid job. I commend him on the job he is doing in encouraging export development.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that this Bill to create the Australian Trade Commission will simply bring about a change for the better. We shall see the opportunity created for market programs and promotion; we shall see a co-ordination which has been lacking in the past. The Government does not walk away from its responsi-bilities to take a far-sighted and detailed role in promoting Australia's exports and competitive advantage in the overseas markets. I think that, as with all our policies since we have been in government, this organisation too will work effectively and should be promoted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Australian Trade Commission Bill I point out that its alleged aim is to streamline the Australian Trade Commissioner Service. That is nice rhetoric and it might look good to create a new bureaucratic monster, to set up a new organisation and to reshuffle the deck chairs on the Titanic, but I believe it will be only marginal in helping Australia's export industries. One has to attack fundamentals rather than create a new trade commission organisation to ensure the success of Australia as an exporter. The Bill will create a new bureaucratic monster without attacking or addressing the fundamental problems facing Australia and its economy.

SPEECH.PARA: This week's balance of trade figures show a complete failure of the Government's trade, economic and financial policies. They are quite devastating-a $1.6 billion deficit for October, the most damaging that we have had. It is a direct result of the Government's failure to discount wages and of the failure of the accord, which is the centrepiece of the Government's economic policy in governing the nation. That failure puts Australia economically out of balance with the rest of the world.

The accord is an agreement between the political and industrial wings of the Australian Labor Party, and I believe that it is the high point of union power by which this Government's wages and economic policies are determined. It is a written agreement which has just been renewed between the parent on the one hand and the child-namely, the parliamentary wing of the industrial trade union movement, the Australian Labor Party, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I repeat that the accord is the high point of union power. There is a written agreement dictating to the Government how it will govern and what its wages and economic policies will be. Here in Australia today the unions possess unprecedented power.
