Because of the accord, which automatically passes on inflation through a centralised wage fixing system and there has just been a 3.8 per cent increase under wage indexation passed on to Australia's wage earners as a result of the accord and the Government's economic policy-we have paid ourselves more than we can afford. Australia's export industries and the economy are becoming less competitive by the day. That is why the balance of trade figures to which I referred earlier for the month of October are so devastating. The deficit on our balance of trade is a direct result of the accord, the failure of the Government's wages and economic policies, and the Government's failure to address the competitiveness of Australian industry because of the high wage cost structure system.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are technically bankrupt.

—Yes, we are technically bankrupt. We have failed and the accord locks us into a rigid system. We have failed to have what we need, and that is a flexible, less rigid system, because that is the way to address our exports. The Government should be looking at the fundamentals of the economy-at how we increase exports and how we make Australia more competitive. We need to address the whole wages structure. That is the way to have an efficient economy rather than to have the charade of this legislation which is now before the House and which is creating a new bureaucratic monster.

SPEECH.PARA: The accord locks Australian employers into paying automatic wage indexation without any notice being taken of the capacity of an individual firm, enterprise or industry to pay or of its profitability. Recently across the board the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission awarded a 3.8 per cent wage increase. This again is a direct result of the accord, the policies that flow from it and the deal between the ACTU and the Government. This is why Australian farmers, miners and small businesses are becoming uncompetitive. They cannot negotiate different terms, conditions and wage rates according to the capacity of an industry to pay and according to profitability, because of this rigid, inflexible, institutionalised accord under an equally inflexible and institutionalised Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Those are the fundamentals which this Government should be looking at rather than coming to the House with the charade of a new Australian Trade Commissioner Service, and that is the way to help improve exports.

As I have said, the accord sets the Government's policies and the Government is presiding over a most serious deterioration in Australia's trading performance. Ministers admit it. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who has spoken in this debate, congratulated the Minister for Trade on his frankness that over the past 30 years Australia has slipped as an exporter from eighth to twenty-third place. I have already said that the October trade figures are quite devastating. They comprise an all-time record for the last three years. Over the past three years our net balance of payments on current account, including the October figure, is $29 billion-a devastating current account deficit.

The Bill does not address fundamental matters that vitally affect trade. As an exporter Australia is falling behind the rest of the world daily because of our uncompetitive cost structure and wages system as a direct result of the accord. We are losing ground daily. We have lost ground in the major markets to which we export-Japan and the Association of South East Asian Nations. We have a pitifully poor export performance.

The Government has deregulated the financial system and the Opposition has been constructive in welcoming that. It has freed the Australian dollar, which is now subject to international market forces. Its value is that which buyers and sellers put on it when buying and selling Australian currency.

On the one hand the Government has de-regulated the financial system and freed up the dollar, but it has not deregulated the wages system. As I have said, we still have a rigid, inflexible wages system which is highly centralised. In addition to its highly centralised nature, we now have this accord document to which I referred, which is the high point of union power in giving automatic wage indexation. The Australian economy now has a nearly deregulated financial system and a freed up dollar which is subject to international market forces, but it has an institutionalised, rigid and inflexible wages system. So there is a massive distortion in the economy because of the failure to deregulate wages. This Government is unable to deregulate wages. It is a prisoner of the trade union movement at any time, but it is now locked in by virtue of a written agreement called the accord. We need a flexible wages system whereby employers and employees within an industry can negotiate terms and conditions of employment according to the capacity to pay. That is how we will get increased export performance and more competitive Australian exporters and businesses. This lack of confidence of overseas investors in the Australian dollar is the reason for the record high interest rates we have at the present time, which again adds to the circle of uncompetitiveness of Australian industry. High interest rates add to the costs of the farmers about whom I spoke, the miners and the small businesses.

A slow-down in the economy is starting to occur. We have talked in this House on previous occasions about the slow-down and its effect on home owners in the increased payments they will have to meet because of the record high real interest rates in this country. We will have a slow-down in investment. The uncompetitiveness of Australian industry on export markets is a direct result of the failure of the Government to discount wages-it cannot do so under the accord-for the full effect of the devaluation of the dollar. International markets have judged Australia as a poor performer as an exporter and as a nation because of the high cost structure and the nature of this inflexible wages system. That is why we have record high interest rates and that is why the circle is going round and round. Unless the Government grasps the nettle and discounts wages for the full effect of the devaluation that has occurred, we will become more and more uncompetitive. We are competitive now, with an inflation rate that is double that of our major trading partners. We are living in a fool's paradise. We have to take our own medicine. We have to discount wages for the devaluation of the Australian dollar. We have to reduce in real terms Australian wages. That is the only way we will have a competitive economy, competitive exporters, miners, farmers and small businesses.

I move on to another matter in relation to the Trade Commissioner Service, that is, the appointment of Mr David Combe to the position of Australia's Trade Commissioner in Vancouver. I am most concerned that prior to Mr Combe's taking up his appointment recently the area of responsibility of the Australian Trade Commissioner Service in Vancouver was changed. Apparently the Vancouver Trade Commissioner Service office previously had responsibility for the State of Washington in the United States. The State of Washington, which is next door to British Columbia in Canada, has important defence facilities. Apparently the Government has now arranged that Australian trade with Washington State, which is important, will be dealt with from the San Francisco office of the Trade Commissioner Service instead of the Vancouver office. Mr Combe has been prevented from acting as Consul-General within the Washington State of the United States, which was apparently normal practice before Mr Combe took up his appointment.

The Minister for Trade is in the House today and it is important that he should explain to the House the reasons for the change in the area of responsibility in this so-called streamlined Trade Commissioner Service provided for in the Bill we are now debating. Is this appointment the way to run an efficient trade office, particularly as San Francisco is five times further from Washington State than Vancouver? This changed arrangement to which I have referred in the administration of the Vancouver office of the Trade Commissioner Service and Mr Combe's appointment is the last so far, in a series of unexplained actions by this Government. The Melbourne Herald newspaper raised on a number of occasions questions about Mr Combe's appointment. On 29 July it asked a number of questions. We have a Bill before the House which is trying to streamline the Trade Commissioner Service, yet we have an appointment which has damaged morale in that Service.

I have raised a question about efficiency in relation to Canada and the State of Washington. There are legitimate questions which need to be answered by the Government about the appointment of Mr Combe as Trade Commissioner in Vancouver. I believe that the Minister and the Government owe the House and the nation a complete explanation of the details concerning Mr Combe's appointment. The Government must answer the following questions: Why was the area of responsibility covered by the Vancouver office changed; who was the previous occupant of the position in Vancouver; why did that person vacate the position; were there any other candidates for the Vancouver Trade Commissioner job; were any interviews conducted for the position; was any person appointed, but the appointment not announced, prior to Mr Combe's appointment to the job; was that person subsequently told that he or she did not have that appointment; were any other positions offered to Mr Combe prior to his appointment; was the appointment made by Cabinet-perhaps our colleagues opposite could tell us whether the appointment was approved by Caucus-and was the appointment a pay-off for the damage Mr Combe suffered because of the shabby treatment he received from the Government during the Ivanov affair? I believe that the Minister owes the Parliament an explanation. The House should be given the complete reasons for Mr Combe's appointment as Trade Commissioner in Vancouver, and this debate on this legislation on the Australian Trade Commission legislation provides the Minister with an opportunity to do that.

In conclusion, I raise one other issue about Australian exports, mainly the rural exports which are important to Australia. The position under the European common agricultural policy is that European producers are dumping their rural goods on our markets and are taking traditional European markets from us because of their highly subsidised agriculture. The common agricultural policy in Europe is the result of a very strong rural lobby. I believe that this Government-and previous governments for that matter-have forgotten the consumers in European capitals and cities with whom we have common interests. Australian exporters and the Australian economy and nation have similar interests to those of European consumers; that is, the provision of low cost, high quality rural products. I believe that the Trade Commissioner Service and the Government should make diplomatic efforts to work with and lobby members of the parliaments of Europe, the individual nation states, the European Economic Community and the European Parliament. Similarly, I believe that the Government should lobby and work with consumer groups in Europe in the common interest of Australian exporters to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of Australia's exporters to Europe and the rest of the world. I thank the House.

The Commission will act as a one stop trade shop providing exporters with a full range of appropriate advice and packages of assistance drawing on all the Government's resources. This is an important aspect of this legislation. It will streamline the service that we can offer to exporters. SPEECH.PARA: At first glance, given the description by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) of the new Australian Trade Commission as a one stop trade shop, it might have been thought that the new Trade Commission was a step in the right direction. It might seem that the drawing together of a number of different agencies under a single umbrella would assist Australian exporters and lead to a rationalisation of the multiplicity of corporations, boards, services and departmental authorities that have grown up in inverse proportion to Australia's declining export performance. However, a number of factors demonstrate that, in fact, the establishment of a new statutory authority, less answerable to either the Minister or Parliament, is a step backwards. A major factor is that the Minister's plans to establish the Commission have already failed to gain the support of the very people that the Commission is supposed to assist-Australia's business community.

One might have thought that this Government, which is fond of proclaiming its special relationship with big business and congratulating itself on its record of consultation with industry leaders, might have asked Australia's present day and potential exporters how government might best assist them. Instead, the Minister comes to this House with a proposal that is transparently a product of bureaucratic empire building and the Minister's desire to be seen to be doing something on a grand scale. We are told that the new Commission will have a staff of some 1,400 people, and a budget in the order of $200m. It is clear from this that the new Commission will take on the full staffing and budgetary commitments of the various agencies that are to come under its wing.

My inquiries have revealed that the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation has 96 staff, that the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation has 14 people working for it, that the Export Development Grants Board has 94 staff and that the Trade Commissioner Service some 550 people, of which 150 are based in Australia. Presumably the other 650 people to be employed by the Trade Commission are those presently working in the marketing and promotion areas of the Department of Trade. It is clear, firstly, that in establishing the new Commission the Minister has made no attempt to use the opportunity to reduce staffing levels-an attempt which one might have hoped would be a natural outcome of any decision to rationalise a number of agencies under the one roof. Secondly, and even more seriously, it is clear that the new Commission-a semi-autonomous and semi-commercial organisation-will start out burdened by the accrued, collective superannuation, long service leave, rights and entitlements of 1,400 public servants.

The Minister offers no division of expenditure of the $200m budget for the Commission, but this House can assume that by far the greatest proportion will go towards fulfilling staff entitlements, rather than doing the job for which the Commission is designed-improving Australia's export performance. The Minister's record of performance in this portfolio has not been encouraging. Since the Minister took on this responsibility, the public's attention has been drawn to a number of interdepartmental squabbles between Treasury and Trade, and between Foreign Affairs and Trade, and conflict between the Minister and the departmental head about the Minister's apparent insecurity on policy making and public comment. Meanwhile, the Australian Chamber of Commerce earlier this year attacked the concept of an overseas trading corporation, apparently proposed by the Department, and overseas the sudden withdrawal of senior Trade Department officials in London, Brussels and Geneva has left both foreign and Australian businesses in a state of confusion.

Given this muddle-headed record of administration and policy making, and given Australia's relentless decline as an exporting nation, it might be useful to the Minister to learn of successful approaches to the question of export encouragement undertaken by a country which, like Australia, is faced with a small domestic market and a resultant need to export to grow-to coin an old slogan. About nine years ago Sweden, a high cost country, which as the Minister would be aware has just half of Australia's population, completely reorganised its trade promotion efforts by establishing the Swedish Trade Council. A recent survey shows that Sweden now rates sixth on a list of 28 countries in international competitiveness, while Australia ranks sixteenth, having slipped from twelfth position in the past year. That might, incidentally, give the Treasurer (Mr Keating) something to talk about next time he is chatting with Simon Crean and Bill Kelty.

However, my purpose is to give the Minister for Trade something to think about as he creates this monolithic statutory authority, and therefore I will acquaint him with the nature of Sweden's Trade Council-its equivalent of the Australian Trade Commission. The most relevant consideration is that the Swedish Trade Council is financed 50 per cent by government and 50 per cent by private enterprise. Its board is constituted from government and private enterprise in the same proportions. There are some 3,600 private enterprise members of the Council, who between them contribute some $27m-at today's exchange rate, so it will probably be different tomorrow-to the Council's budget, through membership and consultancy fees. The most significant point, of course, is that the Swedish business community is 100 per cent involved in and supportive of its country's export promotion and marketing organisation.

We might compare that with the understandable lack of enthusiasm and unmitigated apathy shown towards the Minister's Trade Commission by the Australian business community. That is understandable, because it was not consulted and will not be involved. Simply stated, and in stark contrast to the successful Swedish model, Australian manufacturers and exporters are having imposed upon them a bureaucratic body for which they did not ask and they do not want.

There are other lessons to be learnt from the Swedish experience and, of course, we could do with some in light of this month's trade figures. For instance, the Swedish Trade Council has a total annual budget of around $70m-as against $200m-and a total staff of 432-as against 1,400-including overseas employees manning 70 overseas offices, including two in Australia. There cannot, of course, be any justification for saying that because Australia has twice Sweden's population, it should have twice the number of employees in its overseas offices and twice the budget. Even taking into account the extra effort needed in export promotion and marketing, the $200m budget and 1,400 staff proposed by the Minister is clearly a further example of Government extravagance at its worst.

It is ironic that this Government's response to its mammoth current account and trade deficit is to throw even more taxpayers' money at the problem. The total cost to the Swedish taxpayer of the Swedish Trade Council this year will be about $35m. With this new Commission, Australian taxpayers will be charged approximately six times as much for much less benefit.

Lastly, the Minister might like to note that trade commissioners, market managers and assistant trade commissioners employed by the Swedish Trade Council are drawn not from the bureaucracy but from private enterprise. Indeed, they must have at least 10 years experience in export enterprise plus overseas experience in order to qualify for these jobs. They have a maximum term of five years in the job, at one post in one country, and then return to private enterprise life. Quite apart from the level of experience, stability and understanding such a system must bring to the Council's trade offices, the Minister should positively salivate at the implied savings in superannuation and long service leave that such a system would mean. I recommend most strongly that the Minister reconsider his approach, and he would do well to study the trade commission models established by the successful exporting countries of the world. He could do worse than give the Swedish Trade Council office in Melbourne a ring if he is short on ideas. The monolithic and extravagant Commission that the Minister seeks to impose upon Australian exporters and taxpayers will become just one more expensive and entrenched institution, outside the direct supervision of this Parliament or the responsible Minister. The Minister has shown rare honesty in detailing Australia's poor international performance, which must have left his colleagues breathless. They are constantly telling the country how well we are doing economically.

I would also recommend to the Minister a paper from the Australian National University's Centre for Economic Policy Research, by visiting Professor Olson, and the Brookings study, `A View from the North' which both clearly demonstrate that Australia's rush to protectionism earlier this century has created today's trade deficit difficulties. `The View from the North' has nothing to do with the Northern Territory, being a view from the Northern Hemisphere, but it coincides very well with the view from the Northern Territory. The Territory is now establishing a trade development zone-the first such in Australia, although there are hundreds in the United States of America. Our zone faces the greatest economic growth centre of the world today in Asia and the Pacific, and the Northern Territory is undertaking, even in the face of Federal Government inertia, plans that could transform the nature of Australia's trade routes and priorities. The Northern Territory, like all Australia, has a very big stake in the future of Australia's trade performance. I know that the Territory Government and territory enterprise would be only too happy to advise the Minister on ways to go about increasing our trade prospects. I am sure that the Australian business community would also welcome the chance to be involved in a real way in trade promotion efforts.
I ask the Minister to withdraw this Bill-a second time-and bring back to this House a proposal that will have the support and involvement of the Australian exporters of tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian Trade Commission Bill is to establish the Australian Trade Commission as a statutory authority to consolidate and improve the Federal Government's support for export marketing activities. This Bill will enable the bringing together and integration of the various operational arms of the Trade portfolio into a single statutory authority. These are: The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation, the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation, the Export Development Grants Board, the Trade Commissioner Service, and the marketing, promotion and relevant management areas of the Department of Trade. I am informed that the functions of the Commission are primarily to develop and implement programs to facilitate and encourage the export of Australian goods and services. As previous speakers have said, the Commission will act as a one stop trade shop. It will provide exporters with the full range of appropriate advice and packages of assistance, The enormous resources of the Federal Government will be available to the Commission. The Hawke Government, an authentic Australian government, is determined that the Commission will have the benefit of the best business knowledge and experience available. Australia's export marketing efforts will be strengthened and made more effective.

SPEECH.PARA: The urgent need for Australia to lift its export performance is evident to all. Unless Australia is able to lift its export performance dramatically and quickly, Australians face a sharp drop in living standards. The task before the Commission is immense. Years of incompetent Liberal-National Party government have almost extinguished Australia's export competitiveness. Australian manufacturers export only 8 per cent of goods while countries with similar living standards to Australia export up to 30 per cent of their manufactured goods.

Australians will never forget that for 30 of the last 35 years the Liberal-National Party held Federal Government. During this time the Liberal-National Party presided over policies which saw Australia slip from eighth to twenty-third in world export rankings. Over the last 30 years, for most of which the Opposition was pretending to govern, Australia's share of the world export market slipped from 2.6 per cent to 1.2 per cent. While the Opposition governed, Australia lost ground in most major overseas markets including Japan, the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations and the western Pacific. For example, Australia's share of imports fell from 8.4 per cent in 1970 to 5.3 per cent in 1980, a fall of 37 per cent. Australia's share of imports by the ASEAN countries fell 30 per cent. Machinery accounted for some 30 per cent of all goods imported by the ASEAN countries in the 1970s. Australia's share of imports of these goods by the ASEAN countries fell from 2.2 per cent in 1970 to a mere 0.9 per cent in 1980.

Liberal-National Party policies resulted in the dominance-unusual by comparison with other major industrialised nations-of agricultural and mineral commodities in Australia's export mix and in the lack of real commitment by manufacturing industry in Australia to export: The Liberal-National Party coalition blamed Australian workers and said their wages were too high. But wages in Sweden are just as high and still Sweden has a thriving manufacturing export industry. The Hawke Government recognises that Australia's export performance will not be lifted by a single measure. Only a cohesive and co-ordinated set of policies, pursued with determination by government and industry, will create the economic environment essential for Australia's recovery as a major trading nation. Greater export of manufactured goods and services will be a major factor in rolling back unemployment. It is fact that for every $100m in exports, 5000 jobs are created.

But all is not gloom. Australia is well placed geographically in the world's highest growth region. Australians are a skilled and inventive people, capable of designing and supplying quality products and services for world consumption, and there are many export success stories to learn from. The North Queensland region has a long history of exporting and has continued to develop new markets and new products. In 1983-84 exports from the North Queensland region amounted to $2,234,206,000-or 44.11 per cent of the Queensland total. On 11 November 1983, I opened the Townsville office of the Department of Trade. It was the first regional trade office located outside the capital cities. It was opened for one purpose-to service the strong export potential of North Queensland.

Since the establishment of this office, transport infrastructure is being improved. Direct air freight linkages now exist with New Zealand, Singapore, the United States, Canada, Papua New Guinea and Irian Jaya. There has been a growth in new industries. Manufacturing industries include building materials, agricultural machinery, mining machinery and service, clothing, copper products, ethyl alcohol, food supplements and boats. New and expanding industries involving the production of fruit and vegetables, prefabricated housing, mariculture, security devices and food supplements are looking to export markets. Manufacturers are becoming more diversified and employment and exports generated by them are on the increase, with regular shipping from Cairns to Port Moresby. Papua New Guinea is now developing as a market for building materials and machinery, prefabricated housing and related products, agricultural and mining machinery and servicing, and pipeline systems. A high level of interest has been achieved and firms are beginnning to team together to offer better packages. In addition, North Queensland firms have been encouraged to apply for Papua New Guinea franchises to increase market penetration. Mining equipment, boats, seafood and security equipment are considered to have good prospects in North America. The Townsville office of the Department of Trade has assisted with market research and the seafood industry in particular has made considerable inroads. Boating has been identified as being a major growth industry in North Queensland and local manufacturers are already seeking assistance in entering the lucrative American market.

The long term future of the northern fruit and vegetable industry is largely dependent on the exploitation of the ASEAN market. The findings of the Australian fresh tropical fruit and vegetable survey mission to South East Asia in 1984 have been of assistance to northern growers and much ongoing work is taking place, generated in part by crop diversification away from sugar and the Burdekin Dam due for completion in the near future. Having a direct air link between Townsville and Auckland allows for the quick movement of air freight to New Zealand. However, North Queensland is faced with stringent New Zealand quarantine regulations that have prevented large sales of fruits and vegetables in the past. New Zealand is considered to have good potential as a market for tropical fruits and vegetables.

The reduction of shipping services from Cairns, Townsville and Mackay is of concern to north Queensland exporters. The withdrawal of Australian National Line and scan carrier links has impaired the region's ability to export and has forced some major mineral producers to charter shipping or freight goods south to Brisbane. Cargo centralisation of beef exports in southern ports has deprived Townsville of export trade of some 3,600 containers a year to the United States. Nevertheless, through the application of new technologies and processes in existing manufacturing operations, north Queensland exporters now have a chance to improve their overall cost structure significantly. This can only serve to increase exports from north Queensland.

While there has been outstanding success by the Townsville office of the Department of Trade, it is clear that Australia's export recovery simply will not happen if its exports continue to be concentrated in the slowest growing segments of international trade-bulk agricultural commodities and minerals. Indeed, Alan Goodall, writing in the Australian of 1 February 1985, observed:

In the medium to longer term, growth in import demand for agricultural products is expected to slow. The outlook for the mining sector does not suggest an overall major recovery from current low prices.
In the same article, Mr Bill Ferris, whose national export marketing strategy panel produced a major report-sometimes seen as the basis for government-led export reforms-is reported as saying:

We cannot, as a nation, continue with a manufactures sector which earns only 9 per cent of its revenues from overseas sales and contributes only 20 per cent of total national export income. Similarly, with the services sector, Australia's poor performance in exporting manufactures does not flow from demand factors but from the uncompetitiveness of our manufacturing base and the absence of a sufficiently outward looking commitment to growth. Both are within our power to solve.

The Liberal-National parties have a lot to answer for. The long term lack of co-ordinated national industry policies and insufficient export support has been a major factor in Australia's poor export performance because it has prevented manufacturers from utilising Australia's resources to best advantage in establishing a national brand image. Australia's export performance clearly is out of kilter. In the excessive dependence on agricultural and mineral exports Australia's trade pattern has more in common with developing economies than industrialised countries.

Many Australian manufacturers have neglected two basic requirements of any business-an entrepreneurial instinct and good salesmanship. For too long, they were content to rely on the domestic market without seriously considering exports. It is plain that many of them are unfamiliar with foreign currency transactions, trade regulations, Customs practices, export finance, overseas markets intelligence and foreign business customs. Despite abundant evidence to the contrary, many manufacturers have come to believe that exporting is not worth the effort and that their products are unacceptable.

Australia's strength in manufacturing exports lies in the area of middle level technology, where manufacturers already have a very confident command of what is involved and a well established base, rather than chasing high technology rainbows. Australia can no longer ride on the back of commodity exports. One way Australians can raise their standard of living is through export income earned from manufactures and services. The Hawke Government has an outstanding record in providing a climate conducive to export. To sum up: These Bills are further evidence of the Hawke Government's commitment to national reconstruction, national recovery and national reconciliation.

Let me just make a few observations, as we are dealing with the Bill as a whole. I thank honourable members for their contribution to the second reading debate. I will make a few observations about the contribution particularly from the Opposition and the Opposition's decision to oppose this legislation. In the first instance I must say that, running through the Opposition's contributions, was a lamentable mishmash of confusion and ideological prejudice concerning the intentions of this legislation. Much of the contributions from the Opposition centred around the appropriateness or otherwise of Australia's current macro-economic policy as it affects our trading performance. It should not be necessary for me to point out that the legislation before us is not at all to create for macro-economic policy, but rather to establish an agency to support exporters and to improve the marketing effort of Australia generally and of our individual exporters. I think that is the important point. The important point that we are trying to make in the establishment of this organisation is to bring together all the existing services which have been supported by successive governments, extended from time to time into new areas, to provide those services more efficiently and, most importantly, in a way which is more relevant to the needs of Australian exporters.

Frankly I find it beyond comprehension that this legislation could be characterised as part of this Government's onward march of nationalisation, as was done by the Opposition spokesman in this area. The simple point is that we are bringing together some existing agencies. In almost every respect, the powers which exist within the existing legislation, most of which were supported by the previous Government, if not enacted by it, have been carried forward into this legislation. The great difference is that we are centralising those services under one board. That board will be comprised overwhelmingly of private sector representatives. To suggest that people of the character of Kevan Gosper of Shell, Peter Cotterell of Email, Brian Scott, formerly of W. D. Scott and Bill Ferris of Barlow Marine Ltd and the others would be agents for the nationalisation of Australia's trade effort is just simply beyond belief. They have joined the interim board not only because of the great contribution they can make to the establishment of this Commission, but also because they recognise that here is a great improvement that can be effected to improve Australia's trading performance and to extend to Australian exporters a better and more relevant service.

I want to take up one point made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) who, in his criticism of this legislation, held up the Swedish Trade Council, which of course was established by the wicked socialist government which has been running Sweden for most of the time since the war. The point that he was making was that the great success of the Swedish Trade Council was that it effectively brought government and the business sector together through one agency and it provided for cost sharing between the public sector and the private sectors in the export promotion effort. That is precisely what we are doing here. The board will ensure that the Government, through its activities, will be able to relate more effectively with the private sector. In the course of establishing this Commission we will provide for some measure of cost recovery or fee for service for the services which are provided by the Commission-a point which apparently the honourable member for the Northern Territory welcomes, although I think there would be very few people in Australia who would think that we ought to go to the point of 50 per cent cost recovery, which is what he appeared to be suggesting.

The other point I want to make is in regard to the major arm of the Commonwealth's effort in this area, through the Australian Trade Commissioner Service and through the trade promotion and publicity area. Never before has there been any effective influence by the private sector or exporters generally on how that Service is managed or directed. What we now have is the opportunity through the board of the Commission for the private sector to be involved in the management and the running, and indeed the financing, of those two very important services. Australia has nothing to apologise for. We have one of the best trade commissioner services any- where in the world. In fact ours has been a model for similar services in many other countries. But what we did need to do in the context of our current circumstances was to improve on it by effecting some efficiencies and rationalisations which would ensure that the dollars provided either by the taxpayer or by the exporters purchasing the services provide the greatest possible assistance to our Australian exporters, particularly those medium and smaller exporters who are involved in the export of manufactured goods and services.

On the point of whether this move has been opposed by business interests in Australia, there has been very detailed consultation with the organisations representative of export interests, both by me directly and by officers of my Department and indeed by members of the interim board. Almost universally we have found this measure welcomed by those interests. Of course, they have had questions to ask about certain aspects of it. We have involved them in a detailed process of consultation as we have worked through those problems. Practically no opposition has been communicated to me with regard to the establishment of this Commission. To the extent that there have been concerns, they have been related largely to whether or not there should be cost recovery, and I make no apologies for that. Where services are being provided which can command a price, the Government in this area and in other areas has an obligation to seek to recover the cost of the services being provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Trade Commission Bill was introduced by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins). It is, in his own words, of very great significance. The theory of all that sounds wonderful but he also went on to suggest that by creating a statutory authority it will remove the Trade Commissioner Service further from the scrutiny of Parliament and no doubt he sees some benefit in a hands-off approach by the Minister by virtue of its being a statutory authority.

SPEECH.PARA: One has to question the veracity of the claims of the Minister on this aspect, particularly with regard to his actions as distinct from his words. He has just emphasised that the Trade Commissioner Service is probably among the best in the world and he noted that it was also the basis for comparison with and a model for other countries. That may be but I strongly suggest that that has in the past been because the personnel made available through the Department of Trade for the service has generally comprised men and women of high quality. Unfortunately, however, in July of this year, the Minister, on his own initiative, decided to appoint to the Trade Commissioner Service Mr David Combe. The Minister's Press release of 17 July stated:

Mr Dawkins said that the Trade Commissioner Service needed people with good promotional and representational skills such as Mr Combe possesses. The Government reached the conclusion that Mr Combe's widely recognised talents and experience would be an asset . . .

The Committee has a right to know what these widely recognised talents are. Perhaps we should look to the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security Agencies which was established by the Government following the intense embarrassment caused by Mr Combe's rather strange relationship with a functionary of the Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The comments on Mr Combe's character in the report of the Royal Commission were as follows:

The evidence satisfies me that Mr Ivanov, who had demonstrated that he was an active KGB officer, was cultivating Mr Combe, whom he perceived to be sympathetic to certain aims of the Soviet Union, and who possessed attributes which made him an attractive target for recruitment. Those attributes included access to Ministers and senior levels of government, a desire to make a good deal of money quickly, a hostility to the CIA and, therefore, probably to other secret intelligence services, a willingness to seek and declare friendship with Soviet citizens and a keenness to see an improvement of relations between Australia and the USSR to which he was prepared to actively contribute.
So much for the special and widely recognised talents and experience which we are told by the Minister that Mr Combe has had in terms of his ability to serve Australia.

The saga of Mr David Combe's appointment, from its inception last July, has been surrounded by nothing short of duplicity. His great mentor, the Minister for Trade, had to obtain the support of key Cabinet colleagues to ensure endorsement of the proposed appointment. He managed to obtain the agreement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and, in an attempt to win the support of the New South Wales Right, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). Senator Richardson, to his credit, saw the potential danger of the right faction being associated with this appointment and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism found himself somewhat alone in his own State.

But this tinpot machiavellian Minister for Trade, on advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs and from his own Department, realised later that Mr Combe's appointment to Vancouver on the basis of the post's existing geographic responsibilities would require the agreement of the United States Government as well as that of the Canadian Government because the Vancouver post has for some years been responsible for the State of Washington. This would have given Combe as Australia's Consul-General as well as Trade Commissioner access to the Boeing plants in Seattle, a major naval base of the United States fleet in the same city and other highly sensitive United States defence facilities in that area. With his background of pro-Soviet sympathies, there was a clear risk for the Government that the United States, if asked to approve his appointment as Consul-General, would have raised questions about that appointment. In the face of this potential embarrassment the Government simply changed the administrative arrangements for the post and gave Washington State to the Consul-General in San Francisco to administer.

Despite this, the Minister for Trade has persisted in claiming that David Combe has a clean bill of health and was fully exonerated. I ask: By whom? Was it the Caucus of the Australian Labor Party? This Government has put its responsibilities to Australia second to its alleged duties to its mates. These are issues which are of considerable importance to the Australian people. Whilst there has not been much Press about this appointment, let it go on record that this Opposition will not sit by and permit the Australian Trade Commissioner Service to be used as a political tool of this Government. Any appointments which have been made by this Government, such as Mr Combe's appointment, will no doubt be given the most rigorous investigation in due course. At a time of impending crisis in Australia's trade position, this is not the way to run an efficient trade office and it surely must be detrimental to Australia's trade prospects.

With regard to both the Canadian authorities and the United States authorities, whatever their formal position may be vis-a-vis their relationship with the Australian Government, the indisputable fact is that they have been concerned about their appointment; because of that the access which Mr Combe would normally expect from our North American allies may well be limited as a result. In a nation which it is claimed is on its uppers-certainly the policies of this Government have contributed to that-it is clearly necessary that we have representing Australia around the world people of undoubted integrity; people who are not the subject of investigation and great criticism by royal commissions of inquiry into their activities. At the least, we need to have people of sound judgment. Whatever else can be said about David Combe, one could not say on the basis of the record of the famous Iraqi breakfast issue way back in 1975, when Combe at the time of that election was prepared to borrow money from the Iraqi Government of all people to finance the ALP's election campaign, that he has sound judgment. Not satisfied with that we then had the extraordinary relationship between him and the Soviet Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Trade been drawn to a report by the Business Council of Australia that the so-called J curve effect on which the Treasurer relies to justify the Government's economic policies may take much longer to operate than previously thought? What areas of export-primary products, minerals or manufacturing products-does the Minister believe will give the lead in fulfilling the J curve prophecy? When does he believe this will occur?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the National Party of Australia for his question. I hope that we will have the co-operation of the Opposition as we attempt to improve Australia's export performance.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a conjunction of ideas when one thinks of the Leader of the National Party. It has been very discouraging to notice the way in which the Opposition has set about disparaging Australia's economic performance, talking down the economic performance and the economic prospects for Australia. I think that what is important to counterpoint is the fact that whilst, on the one hand, judgments are being made through a somewhat distorted telescope from far away about the performance of the Australian economy, on the other hand, one has the clear vote of confidence on the part of Australian businesses with their investment plans increasing well in advance of those prospects that we had in mind at the time of the Budget, with private fixed capital investment set to increase by 16 per cent during this year. So, quite clearly, there are those in the business community in Australia who do have utter confidence in the prospects for the Australian economy.

ANSWER.PARA: As to precisely where our export performance can improve, it is clear that we have to look across a range of commodities, goods and services. We have, of course, taken into account the somewhat poor prospects for agricultural commodities where one would have expected, in the context of a more active world economy generally, the demand for the commodities which Australia has traditionally produced to increase and the price to increase. For a variety of reasons related to the unfair trading practices of the European Economic Community and the unfair and restrictive trading practices of other countries, of course, those prospects have not been entirely realised. I think it ill becomes anyone from the National Party, or indeed the Liberal Party, to talk about Australia's trading prospects because the deterioration has occurred over the last three decades-not the last three years. TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Defence aware of Peter Robinson's article in the Australian Financial Review of 25 October which relates to the Minister's then recent announcement concerning new construction at Nurrungar? Is the Minister prepared to comment on the assertions in that article that Australia is being short-changed as far as jointness goes and that the electronic shielding being incorporated into the new building is aimed at reducing Australia's ability to supervise United States of America activities at Nurrungar? Is the Minister also able to advise whether, as indicated in the article, Soviet surveillance satellites may be orbiting over Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that the honourable member has provided me with an opportunity to set straight a couple of matters in regard to that article. I wish particularly to do so because Mr Robinson is a respected journalist and the views he puts, particularly on defence matters, carry some considerable weight in the defence community. Firstly, let me reiterate what I said in my Press release of 21 October 1985. The forthcoming construction at Nurrungar is only to provide better accommodation for both Australian and United States staff working at Nurrungar and for the equipment that is housed there. The construction work does not mean any change in the function of the station.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the suggestion that we are being short-changed on jointness let me say categorically that the Australian Government has access to all data for the facilities as and when it wishes and this is a situation we keep constantly under review. Furthermore, it is incorrect to suggest that Australia needs to spy on activities at joint defence facilities. We co-operate with the United States in these places because it supports our shared interests. All activities at the facilities have the knowledge and concurrence of the Australian Government. Australians are integrated into the operations of the facilities and we have access to the product. The shielding referred to is in fact electrical interference shielding, a standard feature of buildings housing computer and communication equipment. As to the suggestion that it is intended to reduce our own knowledge of what is taking place at the facility, there are no circumstances under which this Government would ever be party to such action.

In relation to the comment in the article about Soviet surveillance satellites, it is very well known that the Soviet Union has such satellites and that they pass over Australia, as they do over the rest of the world. There has not previously been an official Australian government announcement stating that this is the case, probably because that information is so well known that little point might be seen in reiterating it. For example, the United States Department of Defense's annual publication Soviet Military Power regularly notes that Soviet military satellites perform such missions. Surveillance satellites can, of course, be of several different types. Some are for photographic reconnaissance, some are radar satellites to locate shipping, and others are for intercepting communications and monitoring other electronic signals and for the detection of missile launches. Some of these satellites are operated in very high or geostationary orbits and others in low. Satellites other than those in geo- stationary orbits pass over Australia up to six times a day and have done so for many years. Australian defence and intelligence authorities assume that these Soviet satellites are used to provide information about developments in our region generally rather than in Australia specifically.

I notice in comments in the Press today that I have been accused by the Central Tablelands No-Base Association of having misled it because originally I indicated that we intended to have the draft environmental impact study completed by November this year and recently I indicated that that study would be completed by February. That is true. I did indicate that the draft EIS would be ready by November, but that judgment was based on the belief that there would be co-operation from the people who would be potentially affected. The non-co- operation campaign, organised by the Central Tablelands No-Base Association, is directly responsible for producing the delays in arriving at conclusions on these matters. It is quite hypocritical of that organisation to claim that in some way or another I have misled it. The situation that has occurred has been largely created by it and the National Party.

The people who are providing us with advice on the environmental study have been able to get on to a substantial number of properties and arrive at some conclusions from them. However, it would be desirable, in order to complete those studies effectively, if they were able to get on to more properties. I remind the people concerned yet again of what an EIS represents in the decision-making process. Holding an EIS of a certain area certainly indicates the Government's predilection to establish a particular institution in that area, but it does not indicate the Government's final decision. If there are serious environmental or social problems that would result from the Government's proceeding on the course on which it had indicated it would proceed, we would expect that to come out in the environmental impact study. It is a process that protects, as far as it can, the interests of the local people in that area.

In not co-operating in the study, the landholders are being very foolish indeed. Their actions are rendered even more foolish because, no matter what, we will complete that study. The present situation creates more uncertainty for the landholders and uncertainty is very undesirable in the economic circumstances in which they find themselves.

We wish to complete that study. We believe that if that study indicates to us that it would be a sensible decision to proceed, it will be very much to the advantage of the bulk of the constituents of the honourable member for Calare, including those whose land would be compulsorily acquired, as they would be very generously treated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no inadequacy on the part of either of my two Ministers today, or for that matter on any other day. The answers they have given have been appropriate and convincing. I make that point in the context that, if we are to talk about the competitiveness of our industries and our capacity to export, a central feature in that capacity will be what happens to wages in Australia. Fortunately, under this Government we have now a wages policy which has produced a level of wage restraint that we have not seen for decades. That will mean, together with the other range of economic policies we are pursuing, that the index of competitiveness of Australian industry will continue to improve as it has done to the point where now the Australian index of competitiveness goes back to what it was at the end of the 1960s.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition has chosen to say that it is this question of industrial relations which more than any other will distinguish the Opposition from the Government. It is therefore a matter of interest that this day the chairman of the Opposition committee on employment and industrial relations has resigned. —Mr Speaker, I am prepared to withdraw that and to give the objective evidence. Now here comes the objective evidence. The Australian this morning carried the headline: `Blow to Howard's policy on unions'. ANSWER.PARA: Dismissing rumours at the time at the impracticability of the measure, Mr Howard said: `I've said all along we want to give the people an option to choose to go outside the system . . . there's no way we have backed away from opting-out'.

It is absolutely central to what they are about. Here is this Leader of the Opposition, who claims to be a man who puts the position honestly and straightforwardly. I ask the honourable members to listen to what he says. He says of opting out:
It's absolutely central to what we are on about.

That is a quote from the Leader of the Opposition in the Australian Financial Review of 2 October 1985. The reason why the honourable member for Lyons has resigned is that he knows that that is not true. As the article in today's Australian points out, there is in existence a document which has been around in the Opposition and the Press Gallery for some time and which establishes that that is not the position of the Opposition. Let us see what the Opposition's central committee on employment and industrial relations had to say about opting out. It is the central committee because the Leader of the Opposition has said that this is the centrally important issue. The committee has said, very simply, that the Leader of the Opposition is not telling the truth. TALK.START.PARA: —You have no answer.
—This is the Opposition's document, which says:

ANSWER.PARA: At three joint meetings of the Opposition Treasury and Employment Industrial Relations Committees . . . a `second stream' proposal was examined, whereby employers and employees could `opt out'--
the Leader of the Opposition's central point-
and engage in a form of collective bargaining. This proposal was further considered by the Employment and Industrial Relations Committee.

Then follow 11 points rejecting the centrality of the Leader of the Opposition's position. I will not go to those points because I will table the document, but that is what was said. The committee's document states, firstly:
None of the experts--

—Order! The honourable member for Lyons will have the opportunity to make his personal explanation later.

—The honourable member for Lyons suggested that it is a fraud. When I have finished referring to the document, I will table it and it will be available for his perusal. It is a three-page document. I will not go through the 11 points in detail, but it is very interesting to see that the 11 points set out in order why the central position of the Leader of the Opposition-that is, opting out-will not work and why it has been rejected. ANSWER.PARA: This House must understand that what has been revealed today is that the Leader of the Opposition, in regard to what he has said is the central issue of wages policy, has been repudiated by his own members. They have set out why the Leader of the Opposition's position is not acceptable; they have rejected it. The position now, as the Treasurer has said, is that the Leader of the Opposition has been repudiated on tax policy and on the central issue of wages policy. As far as the trading position of this country is concerned, it is centrally important to have a wages policy that works. The wages policy of this Government is working. It has produced the lowest level of wage increases in more than a decade. Against that we have a Leader of the Opposition who would give us a wages policy which would lead to an explosion of wages and would give us no chance whatsoever of having any competitive position in the international trading place. The great tragedy is that this country now has a Leader of the Opposition who, in respect of every critical area of economic policy, has gone to water. Worse than that, in the central area of importance his own members have said that he is not telling the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aviation. It relates to the Government's recently announced changes to its international air freight policy. Will the Minister outline the nature of these changes? How will these changes benefit primary producers, particularly those in Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. Because of the importance of having adequate air freight services for primary produce exports and because of the assertion that there was an inadequate capacity available, I decided, after discussions earlier in the year with the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Primary Industry, to commission a review of the then policy. That policy review was carried out by Ted Butcher, a member of the Inter-State Commission, and Jim Scully, a former Secretary to the Department of Trade. The Government's decisions in respect of the report do offer significant new opportunities for primary industry. Our new international air freight charter policy allows for the consolidation of primary produce consignments on outbound flights, together with access to the higher rates of consolidated cargo on inbound flights.

ANSWER.PARA: Previously, all outbound primary produce charter flights were allowed to carry only one type of produce from one consignor to one consignee and did not have access to consolidated cargo inbound. The new arrangements will also assist exports from Australia's smaller international airports by allowing primary produce exports to be picked up from more than one of the secondary gateway airports, such as Cairns, Darwin, Hobart, Norfolk Island, Port Hedland and Townsville. Livestock flights, as at present, will still allow more than one consignor and one consignee. In addition, outbound livestock flights may also carry a mix of primary produce. The question of access to mixed inbound cargo on these flights is a matter that will be considered later by the Ministers I have mentioned and me.

The Government has acted promptly to ensure that adequate air freight capacity is available for primary produce during the current season. As I have said, the new policy offers special opportunities for Western Australian growers and exporters. For example, the report estimated that Western Australia could export an extra 1,500 tonnes of perishables per annum if sufficient space were available. The review was informed that South East Asian markets are increasing by up to 18 per cent per annum and that the producers of Western Australia's south-west could at least double their tonnages to South East Asia over the next three years.

I conclude by saying that a problem was identified. We have dealt with it promptly and expeditiously. I commend the members of the review team for the prompt and able manner in which they carried out that review. The opportunity is there now for primary produce exporters, particularly in Western Australia, to take up the chance to develop their trade, to expand their exports and to raise the sales of their produce.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery the President of the Legislative Council of New South Wales, one of my colleagues in the Commonwealth, the Honourable Johnno Johnson. We give him a warm welcome.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction whether he agrees with the President of the Real Estate Institute of Australia, Mr Sullivan, who said in Canberra this week:

QUESTION.PARA: Both Federal and State Governments should realise they must encourage investment in private rental accommodation to reduce the heavy financial burdens they will otherwise incur through the provision of public housing.
If so, can he advise the House as to how the Government's high interest rate policies and tax changes, especially the capital gains tax and negative gearing changes, will achieve this goal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Deakin cannot do much better than that, we will probably be looking at the third change in 12 months as far as a shadow Minister for Housing and Construction is concerned. In regard to the private rental market in Australia, we have already introduced a depreciation allowance of 4 per cent staight line, across the board, for investors in new construction. That is a far better way of encouraging investment in the private rental market than by doing it through an obvious tax rort like negative gearing, which was run by the previous Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I have already released tables, computer models; information which shows clearly that, as a result of the combination of measures introduced by the Treasurer and by this Government-that is, the quarantining of negative gearing in rental property, a capital gains tax that is entirely prospective and a 4 per cent across the line depreciation allowance-investment in the private rental market, as long as there is a decent and reasonable equity by the investor and a reasonable rate of property appreciation over a period, will still be highly profitable, with an after tax return of up to 14 per cent in that area. Of course, that is a return that is still not available in some other types of investment. We will monitor the situation and, if any vacuums appear, we can look at the situation again. However, it is far too early to say that anything further is required than what we have already done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer inform the House whether the Government is giving consideration to removing or increasing the current 13.5 per cent ceiling on bank home loans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not giving any consideration to removing the ceiling. In fact, it will maintain the ceiling. The Government has made that quite clear. What is interesting is, again, the policy chaos on the other side of the Parliament. Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition was asked by Peter Rapp from the AM program: `Do you want the 13.5 per cent ceiling raised?'. The answer from the Leader of the Opposition was: `No, I want policies changed'. I might just contrast that with a question that the Leader of the Opposition asked me on interest rates in Question Time on 13 September 1985, which appears at page 976 of Hansard. He asked me about the ceiling, and I said:

ANSWER.PARA: Let me just get this right. What the honourable member is saying is that we should lift the housing rate ceiling.

Mr Howard said `Yes'. So, on 13 September 1985 he was for lifting the ceiling on housing interest rates, but yesterday he indicated that he is now for maintaining the ceiling on housing interest rates, that he does not want the policies changed. Expediency just understates massively the change of policy stance by the Leader of the Opposition. Is it any wonder that he is being massively attacked now in newspaper editorials across the country and by his own Party for a lack of any conviction on any issue. Never has a major politician caved in or capitulated more quickly to the forces of opportunism and expediency than the Leader of the Opposition on this occasion.

I indicate that it is not just on this issue. The Prime Minister mentioned both wages and taxation. What we find on taxation is that the Leader of the Opposition now suggests that he should not, as he promised he would do on the day that the tax statement came down, wait and see what the details of the Government's tax policies are; rather, he, the honourable member for Mackellar and Senator Messner sat down on the weekend to sort out their approach to taxation. What came out of it? They decided that they would not reject the whole package but would take the marginal rate reductions and oppose all of the measures introduced by the Government to fund the rate changes. What sort of policy position is that? The Opposition would take all of the reductions and rates and vote against all of the measures which produced the revenue to lower rates. The day before yesterday the Leader of the Opposition, on the Channel 9 program Today, when asked by Mr Liebmann how he would fund it, said:

We would fund them by a broadly indirect tax. We are only talking here of, let's face it, a few hundred million dollars. We are only talking about $1.4 billion from the so-called nasties, and our proposals would relate to $700m or $800m of these. So this argument that in some way we are having it both ways in wanting the tax cuts and opposing the nasties, is a weak argument.

He is saying: `It is only $700m or $800m. We do not need to accept the measures of the Government to pay for these massive tax changes. It is only $700m or $800m'. Here is somebody, who never raised $700m or $800m by expenditure cuts in his whole life as Treasurer, now suggesting that we do not have to worry about it as the Opposition will fund that amount in some other way so that it can take the marginal rate changes and reject, in the most opportunist way, the strength of the Government's tax changes.

So there are these two major issues: Firstly, the Opposition is imploring us to raise the ceiling on housing interest rates but we found yesterday that that apparently is now abandoned due to total policy confusion on interest rates; secondly on taxation, it has a most opportunistic and lowest heel type of approach possible to major tax changes on behalf of a nation, a total blanket opposition to all of the major changes in policy in respect of tax changes. I might say that that is totally opposed to the stated policy of the Opposition when this Government came to office. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle had this to say about government fiscal measures when the Government took office:

. . . a Government is entitled to expect the passage of normal Budget and budget-type legislation and other legislation that is an essential part of its financial program. The Opposition would only act in the Senate to reject or amend such legislation `where it is demonstrated to be capricious and arbitrary or vindictive legislation or where it creates new tax burdens of a retrospective kind'.

In other words, that position outlined by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, when the coalition became the Opposition in 1983, is now to be abandoned. Mr Howard's Opposition will apparently oppose all the tax changes but accept the marginal rate reductions, while at the same time he is imploring the Government to lift the ceiling on interest rates. Then, under pressure of a South Australian election he says no, he does not want the interest rate ceiling lifted.

If that is the stance of the Opposition on two important issues such as interest rates and tax policy, is it any wonder that the Sydney Morning Herald, the Melbourne Herald and a whole stack of other newspapers are attacking the credibility of his leadership and suggesting that he would have no credibility whatsoever as an alternative Prime Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sub-section 67 (2) of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, I present the Australian Federal Police annual report for 1984-85.
