TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, sir.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Thank you. I wish to make a personal explanation on two bases: Firstly, the scurrilous and misleading reports that appeared in this morning's edition of the Australian; secondly, the grossly misleading statements that were made during Question Time by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: I will address my comments firstly to the misrepresentation made by the Prime Minister. During Question Time the Prime Minister made two accusations. Firstly, he said that there was a difference of opinion between myself and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N. A. Brown). Clearly that is not true. There has been the closest of relationships between myself and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, as our shadow Minister-
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that honourable members on my right have the courtesy to allow the honourable member to make his personal explanation.

—As I was saying, there has been the closest of relationships between myself and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, as our spokesman on industrial relations, and there has also been, and always has been, a close relationship between myself and the Leader of the Opposition. I have always felt free to be able to put my points of view to those two gentlemen at any time, knowing they will be listened to clearly and with sympathy. I completely put down any suggestion that there has been any sort of disunity between myself and the Leader and Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The second accusation made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during Question Time was that I had circulated a document, consisting, allegedly, of 11 points. He claimed that that was circulated by me as chairman of the Opposition industrial relations committee. That is not true. I have now received a copy of that document which makes reference to events in 1983. The document is unsigned; there is no name attaching to it. I completely disown that document. If there are accusations circulating in this place that that document originated from me, I completely disown them. It is a fabrication. Any suggestion that the document has come from me is totally wrong and false.

I will now address my remarks to an article that appeared in this morning's edition of the Australian newspaper. As far as I am concerned, that article is totally wrong and misleading. It is evidence of scurrilous journalism at its worst. In the article reference is made to what I presume is the same 11-point document tabled by the Prime Minister. I say again in relation to the article in the Australian newspaper that I have no knowledge of it. That document did not originate with me. As far as I am concerned, that particular document has never been presented to the Opposition industrial relations committee. I saw the document for the first time after it was tabled by the Prime Minister. It is claimed in the article on page 1 of the Australian newspaper:
The chairman of the Industrial Relations Committee, Mr Max Burr, refused to comment on the . . . draft policy or yet another letter, written by him, also obtained by The Australian yesterday.
The article continued:
Mr Burr's letter, circulating in Canberra, points out that the Opposition considered opting-out or `a second stream' proposal last year.

I know of no such letter. If there is such a letter being circulated in Canberra, in the Press Gallery or anywhere else in this place, such a letter did not originate from me. If there is such a document it is fraudulent. I ask the journalist, Mr David O'Reilly, whether he can produce that letter to me so that I might refer it to the Federal Police. Clearly that letter is fraudulent. The article makes reference to a letter. I can only deduce from reference to my files that the comments made in the article in the Australian refer to a letter to the editor of the Age newspaper published on 10 October. That is the only evidence I can find of any letter. Clearly, there is no other letter in circulation. The purpose of this article, I believe, is to try to cause divisions between myself and other members of the Opposition. I re-emphasise the point that there is no such division on this side of the House and that the thrust of this article and the detail claimed in it are totally false and untrue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Prime Minister claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, Mr Speaker. The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) has suggested that I said he circulated the document I put. I did not make a statement that he had circulated it, but I do want to pick up the point now in his reference to the letter in the Age of 10 October-
—Is this a personal explanation?
—Yes, it is. The honourable member referred to his letter of 10 October to the Age.
—Where is the Prime Minister being misrepresented?
—If the honourable member would listen instead of chattering away like a silly little boy, I have indicated-
—Here we go again. Every Friday he goes mad.

—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition does himself no credit. I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I accept that the Prime Minister has corrected one misrepresentation. I trust that this second facet is also a misrepresentation.
—Of course it is, because the honourable member has said that there has been a total fabrication. I just want to establish, quickly out of his own letter, that there is no fabrication, and indeed-

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. As I understand it, the Prime Minister is making a personal explanation about how he has been misrepresented. Clearly in the statement I have just made with reference to the letter published in the Age, I made no reference to the Prime Minister in that process. So, clearly, I did not misrepresent the Prime Minister in that reference.

—Order! May I just rule on this matter. The honourable member for Lyons has, quite clearly, corrected his matter. However, in the course of his remarks he did attribute certain comments to the Prime Minister. I take it that the gravamen of the second part of the Prime Minister's explanation is the complaint of the honourable member for Lyons about what the Prime Minister said in his answer?

—Mr Speaker, this can very quickly be disposed of. In the letter of 10 October by the honourable member for Lyons in his then capacity as chairman of the Opposition committee on employment and industrial relations, he refers to the question of opting out and attacks the Age's correspondent, Michelle Grattan. He said that he would like to correct a misrepresentation that she had made. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Grattan said that the Coalition `would establish a two-strand wage fixing system'--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister is entitled to make a personal explanation if he claims to have been misrepresented. He is now seeking to debate an issue. This is not a correction and it should not be allowed simply because he is the Prime Minister.
—Order! I am listening carefully to the matter.

—Order! There seem to be a number of members here who would like to take this Chair. They seem to have better knowledge of the procedures than I do. I have been listening very carefully to the Prime Minister. He is responding to a point made about him by the honourable member for Lyons. He has indicated that he is bringing it quickly to a conclusion.
—Mr Speaker, as I was saying, the honourable member for Lyons stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Ms Grattan said that the Coalition `would establish a two-strand wage fixing system', and that alongside the awards of the Arbitration Commission there would be `the opportunity for workers and employers in small enterprises to opt out and make their own agreements on wages and conditions'.
He then said in his letter:
That is not true.
We then get in this next paragraph the refutation, out of his own letter, that this document is a fabrication, because he uses the exact language. This is what he said:
In 1983-84 the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Clearly I must object to the line taken by the Prime Minister. If there is a form of misrepresentation in the letter published in the Age, that representation would be against the original author of the article, Ms Michelle Grattan. It clearly makes no reference whatever to the Prime Minister.

—I think that the honourable member for Lyons in raising this point of order has misunderstood my ruling. During his explanation he stated that the Prime Minister had made certain statements about him based on certain documents or whatever. I take it that the Prime Minister is refuting that?
—That is absolutely right, Mr Speaker.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to speak to that point. You will recall that I made two personal explanations, one relating to comments made by the Prime Minister and the other relating to the article appearing in this morning's Age newspaper.
—That is not denied, but it is also possible for the Prime Minister to correct what you said about his statement.
—It can be very quickly brought to a conclusion. In his letter he said:

SPEECH.PARA: That is not true. In 1983-84 the Opposition did consider, thoroughly, a ``second stream'' or ``opting out'' proposal, but decided against it for a number of reasons-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not think the Prime Minister should make a fresh accusation.

—No, I am responding to the proposition that we have engaged in the use of a fabrication. I am showing that in his own letter he has quoted from the document. How can there be a fabrication if in his letter to the Age he quotes from the document which he says he has never seen before?

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. As I understand it, the Prime Minister is making allegations and accusations against the honourable member for Lyons which should be made in a substantive motion under the Standing Orders of this House.
—There is an element of that in it. I call the Prime Minister in conclusion.
—He used the words:

SPEECH.PARA: principally that it was virtually unattainable, constitutionally, and that a second stream-
I ask honourable members to note these words from the letter-
would act as a pacesetter for awards, producing a worse wage outcome for the economy.
Those are the words exactly from this document which stated:
Opting-out therefore raises the prospect of a second stream of wage-fixation acting as a pace-setter for the tribunal . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you prepared to give us your fingerprints?
—Yes, indeed. The document stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Opting-out therefore raises the prospect of a second stream of wage-fixation acting as a pace-setter for the tribunal, and therefore a worse wage outcome rather than a better one.
That language is exactly the same as in the document which he says is a fabrication and that he has not seen before. The honourable member for Lyons knows that that is untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the Prime Minister not proceed on that line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before seeking to make a personal explanation, may I apologise to you, Mr Speaker, and to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I was too hasty in taking my point of order because there was clearly a reference to the Prime Minister and he was entitled to make his personal explanation. I now seek to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition claim to have been misrepresented?

—He may proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition MPs are disturbed that Mr Howard and his deputy and industrial relations spokesman, Mr Neil Brown, remain unable to explain how opting-out would work.
There are reports in Canberra that Mr Brown has admitted privately that it cannot.

There are only two things that I wish to say about that. The statements attributed to me are incorrect. TALK.START.PARA: —That would have to be by way of leave to make a statement, not by indulgence.
—Yes. I have every confidence in the proposal, the substance of which is, in appropriate cases, to provide an alternative system to the inflexible, rigid, compulsory arbitration system in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing I wish to say is that, quite apart from the fact that from my own knowledge the entire article is a collection of quite erroneous statements and, if I might say so, a most unprofessional piece of writing, the author of the article did not have the courtesy or the good sense to approach me to ask me about the matter, despite the fact that he was proposing to write that I held certain views. He did not contact my office and ask for an opinion or a contribution; nor did he contact the office of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) or speak to the Leader of the Opposition about it. For those reasons, the exercise is an entirely unprofessional one and does very little credit to the author of the article.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, `Ringing in the Changes: Telecom's Zonal Charging Policies', was tabled in Parliament on 4 October 1984. On 25 March 1985 I made an interim statement in which I indicated that the report was being thoroughly examined by Telecom Australia and that I would inform the House of the Government's attitude regarding the recommendations in the report as soon as possible. I now wish to table Telecom's considered response to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Committee made 23 recommendations which, in the Committee's view, would promote Telecom's charging policies in metropolitan areas which would be equitable, consistent with Telecom's statutory obligations and adequately responsive to community needs. Since my statement of last March, the Committee has entered a second phase of its inquiry, extending its deliberations to rural and remote areas.

Telecom's principles for the charging of telephone calls throughout Australia were established in 1960 as part of the community telephone plan. Since that time, significant changes have been made with the introduction of community access calling, in 1980, and countrywide calling, in 1983. Telecom now proposes to make further changes in response to the report, `Ringing in the Changes'. These changes will provide further benefits to Telecom customers throughout Australia, particularly in the rapidly expanding outer urban areas of the capital cities. The new zoning arrangements require a great deal of preparatory work. They will take effect in about two years time and, in my view, they represent a sound, long term approach to meet the needs of the community into the 1990s.

In conjunction with the proposed zoning changes, Telecom will be redeveloping its national numbering plan, which has been in operation since 1960, to reflect changes in population growth patterns which have occurred since that time. In doing so, Telecom hopes to introduce a closer relationship between numbering areas, charging district boundaries and telephone directories which will significantly assist in improving customer understanding of Telecom's charging arrangements.

Telecom has accepted many of the 23 recommendations made by the Committee. However, it has indicated that the need for financial responsibility and customer equity means that it is not practicable to fully implement all of the recommendations. A separate response to each recommendation is presented within Telecom's formal response to the report. The benefits which will accrue to customers as a result of the changes proposed to Telecom's zonal charging policies can be summarised as: Increased local call access for outer metropolitan and outer urban customers; increased access at community calling rates, in lieu of trunk rates, for metropolitan and outer urban customers; substantial reductions in charges for trunk calls between zones with centres 25 and 50 kilometres apart within expanded capital city charging districts; reduction in tariffs for certain trunk calls from provincial cities and rural areas adjacent to the capital city; reduction in tariffs for certain trunk calls between customers within expanded charging districts and in adjoining charging districts; and improved customer understanding of the call charges through simplification of the charging structure and alignment of numbering areas, charging district boundaries and telephone directories.

The principles involved in Telecom's response to phase 1 of the Committee's inquiry, into outer metropolitan areas, are directly related to its phase 2 study on rural and remote areas. The response will undoubtedly provide a useful input to the second stage of the Committee's inquiry. I congratulate the Committee for its efforts and Telecom for its positive response to the overall thrust of the recommendations. I present the following paper:
Telecom Australia: Zonal Charging Policies-Ministerial Statement, 15 November 1985.
Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the statement which has just been made by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) it is very enlightening to consider the response of Telecom Australia to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. This is an area which I think affects us all and our constituencies in a very remarkable sense. The wonderful throw-away line `Ringing in the Changes' which is the name for--
—It is a bit creative. You would not understand that.

—No, I am sure that the honourable member would not either. His contribution to this area is well known. We, in opposition, want to address ourselves to the effectiveness of this report. Constant complaints come to my office, on a daily basis, in my capacity as a member of parliament and as previous Opposition spokesman on these matters concerning the Telecom-consumer relationship. The good-will that used to exist in the old Postmaster- General's Department has rapidly fallen away in recent times. These complaints relate to Telecom-consumer relations, not to the overall trunking network or to the service itself. Expectations were built up that the 1960 boundaries of the capital cities in the various areas would be changed, but they have not. People expected to have their areas extended into the 02, 03 or 07 area codes, depending on which major capital city they lived near. Because of the significant suburban sprawl that has occurred in Australia since that time those people expected, and indeed might well have been entitled to have been included, in the major motropolitan networks. That has not occurred. Those honourable members who played a special part in this, particularly the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith)--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Flinders would know as much as the honourable member for Grayndler about these matters. These areas have not been expanded. In my view, the reasons given for it in this report completely miss the point. The point which comes out of this and which we made so much about is that we are going to give away $7m of the income that will flow from this.
—Minister Duffy would be pleased to get it.

—Let us turn the honourable member on and give him a digital machine. The projected loss of $7m a year, which is one of high sales points in the Minister's statement, presupposes two things: Firstly, lower prices do not lead to higher use-in other words, price inelasticity which I think is completely beyond any expectations-secondly, if total revenue of $4,765m last year is taken into consideration over a period of two years $7m will be given up. What a great effort that is! It will be made up in additional years, so that is hardly a point.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that it will cost $18m in capital works to being Telecom's proposals into force over two years. What does that mean? We have to weigh $18m against Telecom's total outlay last year of $1,570m. Big deal! The two expenditures add up to $25m, which in the context of the current year's cash outlay of $5.2 billion, adds up to hardly enough to pay for a round of drinks. To justify the work of the parliamentary Committee, Telecom has given up just a small amount and the Minister swallowed it. He made no other response except to say: `Yes, we will go along with that'. So not much is expected of Telecom's coming response to the Committee's inquiry into rural remote areas. I hope that the honourable members who hold seats in those areas, particularly those who sit on this side of the House, will pay close attention to it. If the best response Telecom can come up with in this regard is the allocation of $25m, spread over two years, to implement some changes-this response from Telecom was totally endorsed by the Government-what goes? God help those in the rural sector when Telecom responds to the report on that sector. I hope that the Committee is looking at what may occur in those areas.

At the back of Telecom's response is a section on implementation. I refer those honourable members who might be listening to it. It is anticipated that some two years will be required for the preparatory work-this is to save $7m. That will be followed by progressive implementation over five years. So everybody can expect that these great cuts-savings of $7m a year-will be phased in over a seven-year period. Big deal! The Government ought to be shocked and horrified by Telecom's response. All people who live in the areas involved and who have been expecting some reforms as a response to the Committee's report have been totally let down.
Debate (on motion by Mr Free) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical locaton on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Hawker and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subvervience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention of the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Goverment of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ``States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26/1/85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Halverson and Mr Hawke.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Scott and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further capital gains and wealth taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of capital gains and wealth taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Ian Cameron.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions or benefits.

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable.
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ``windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Ewen Cameron.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Drummond and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of certain concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers' conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.
4. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
5. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Rocher and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Military Bases in Australia and Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: `For the People's Right to Peace'
`For the Rights of Women and Children'
`For National Independence,
Disarmament and Peace'
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully show:

As a part of the world wide campaign by women in the final year of the United Nations' Decade for Women for `Equality, Development and Peace' (1976-1985) and in view of the grave possibility of nuclear catastrophe, the Union of Australian Women calls on the Australian Government to:
intensify its efforts for nuclear disarmament.
remove U.S. bases from Australian soil.
keep the Pacific and Indian Oceans nuclear free.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Staples and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, we the undersigned call upon all Members to pay due respect to all returned service personnel. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all changes to benefits for veterans', and conditions of service for military personnel, as announced in the May Economic Statement, be withdrawn as to allow sufficient time for sensible community debate before any veteran or service person can be unfairly disadvantaged.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification (ID) cards should be reconsidered and rejected because the system:
(a) is not a cost-effective method of reducing tax evasion and social security fraud and, to the contrary, in the form proposed will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private nature;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the taxpayer; and
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which their introduction is stated to be intended and in fact provide the opportunity for blackmail and other forms of misuse.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which identification cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective and less obnoxious methods.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

that the recent cuts announced in the Mini-Budget to Preschools and Day Care Services are a reversal of A.L.P. policy to make child care services available to all at an affordable cost. Further, that the fee rises arising from the cuts will cause great hardship to the majority of families using these services. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, the Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the May expenditure savings which introduced funding cuts to children's services will cause hardship to many low and middle income earners. Families relying on these vital services will suffer, as will workers within the industry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House fully restores all Federal funding to children's services in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of concerned people of Australia respectfully show their desire that your Honourable House (The Government) act immediately to raise the Tertiary Education Assistance allowance to the level of the Unemployment Benefit.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Councils
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging rural residents with regard to access to the Arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country areas.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Technical and Further Education Participation in Equity Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Technical and Further Education Participation and Equity Programme established as the centre-piece for national youth policy, addresses the educational, social and employment needs of twenty-two thousand unemployed Australian youth. The intended 50% funding cuts will directly affect at least ten thousand already disadvantaged young people, denying them access to further education and potential employment.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the decision to cut the Participation and Equity Programme funding be reversed.
(2) That the Participation and Equity Programme be guaranteed funding for 1987, and beyond.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That pensions be adjusted fully to reflect the total increase in Consumer Price Index (CPI); and
That the ceiling for pensioners' incomes be increased to provide for an adequate `living standard', before any consideration is given to the introduction of reduced pensions and the fall of benefits.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that action be taken by the Government to implement these proposals immediately and not November 1986.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staffing Cuts in Australian Capital Territory Schools and Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers, parents and students working in and for the interests of government schools and TAFE colleges showeth that:
1. We oppose the proposed cuts of 75 teaching and 40 ancillary positions in ACT government schools and 28 teaching positions in ACT TAFE colleges.
2. We deplore the cuts to public education and the harm caused to the opportunities of thousands of Canberra's youth.

3. We call on the Commonwealth Government to honour its primary obligation to public education and its commitments to increase participation and equity in education by not implementing staffing cuts in ACT government schools and TAFE colleges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlment prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satsified with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of three Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any changes to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the guidelines for classification of video tapes and discs for sale and hire issued by the Film Censorship Board places no realistic restriction on the sale to adults of explicit hard-core pornography and, coupled with the widespread existence of video playing machines, little or no realistic family control can now be exercised over the likely viewing of explicit hard-core pornography by children and juveniles.
Noting that the Parliament refused to disallow regulations permitting these circumstances to occur your petitioners therefore pray that:
A Joint Parliamentary Select Committee be established with the following terms of reference:
(a) Examine the extent to which video tapes and discs containing pornographic and violent material are available;
(b) Examine the extent to which children under the age of 18 years obtain access and are exposed to such material;
(c) Investigate the effectiveness of legislative controls upon the dissemination of such material; and
(d) Examine the likely effects of exposure to such material upon children and emotionally disturbed persons.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mail Delays
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the public at large are greatly concerned at excessive mail delays.
2. That we call on the Government to take immediate steps to rectify the service in the interest of the Australian community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Flags Amendment Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That the Flags Amendment Bill, 1984, as presented to the Senate and passed, which ensures that the Australian Flag cannot be changed except by referenda, be brought before the House of Representatives.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
Will ensure that the Flag Amendment Bill, 1984, will be presented to the House of Representatives at the earliest possible time and your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mount St Canice Migrant Centre, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled the Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the only migrant centre in Tasmania, Mount St Canice Centre, be retained for the following reasons:
1. It does not make sense to close this centre and to build 2 others similar to it at a great cost to the taxpayers.
2. The closure of this centre will have devastating effects on the existing networks of migrant services which have taken years of effort and dedication to establish.
3. To close this centre is to say that Tasmania will have no role to play in the immigration programs of this country. Tasmania will be the only state left without such a facility.

4. The closure of the centre can not be justified on a cost basis: the Government locked in an agreement to pay the owner 3 year's rent for the centre. It would therefore be a waste of taxpayer's money.
This decision was made by the Minister for Immigration, Mr Hurford, without consultation, discussion with any groups or individuals who have been involved with the centre.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Entertainment Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That whereas the Government has abolished the one hundred per cent tax deductability status previously applicable in respect of costs incurred by businesses in entertainment expenses, the actions of the Government in this regard will have a significant and negative impact on business and employment in the restaurant industry.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will not proceed with the taxation measures announced on September, 19th, 1985 affecting the tax deductability status of these entertainment expenses.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of Australian residents shows that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any form of compulsory identity cards.

We believe that the introduction of identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in Government revenue.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposals for the introduction of compulsory indentity cards.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

(1) They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission contained in `Funding Policies for Australian Schools', concerning proposed increases in State aid to private schools and the proposed community standard for education funding.

(2) They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to declare a three year moratorium (1985-1987) on increases in State aid to private schools and on grants for new private schools and for increased private school enrolments.

(3) They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to re-affirm their primary obligation to government schools and to implement all 1983 ALP election promises for increased funding to government schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
(1) Create an Australian Ministry for Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-violent resolution of conflict;
(2) Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
(3) Fully support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of the defence budget to fund peace activities;
(4) Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self help development and environmental repair;
(5) Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops;

Holding M.P., enquired into the effects of asbestos mining on the Baryulgil community. The Committee had the following terms of reference:

5. In October 1984 the Chairman of the Committee the Honourable Mr G. L. Hand, M.P., tabled the Report of the Committee in the House of Representatives.

6. The Report of the Committee was published by the Australian Government Publishing Service and made available in bound form. On page 127 of that Report, in paragraph numbered 10.22 beneath the heading `Recommendations. Individual Compensation' the Committee recommended as follows:

7. During the hearings the Committee received certain evidence from Aboriginal Legal Service Ltd and other persons. 8. (d) To an appropriate Officer or Officers of the House to attend in Court as and when necessary to produce the official Report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs titled `The Effects of the Asbestos Mining on the Baryulgil Community' and to give evidence in relation to the conduct of the inquiry which led to that report, providing that such Officer or Officers should not be required to attend at any time which would prevent the performance of his, her or their duties in the Parliament.

Bernard Dominic Brassil
Solicitor of the Supreme
Court of New South Wales

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deteriorating state of the economy due to the Government's high interest rate policies.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe it would be an exaggeration to say that middle Australia faces a living standards and economic crisis, the like of which it has not faced for many years. The essential reason why it faces that crisis is that for the last 2 1/2 years this country, and more particularly the leaders of the Hawke Government, have lived a lie about the effectiveness of the economic policies that this Government has followed. For 2 1/2 years the Hawke Government has been able to get away with the proposition that the policies it has had in place since being elected to office in 1983 have been good ones-policies which have made Australia competitive, have enabled Australia to earn her way in terms of world trade and have made this country competitive in the international arena.

SPEECH.PARA: However, over the past few months a crisis of confidence has developed amongst other countries and within the world finance markets regarding the effectiveness of the policies that the Hawke Government has followed. The inability of the Hawke Government to respond effectively to that changed economic climate flows from the failure of many people in the Government to understand the real implications of the decision that they took-and let me say that it was a decision that was courageously taken by the Hawke Government-in December 1983 to float the exchange rate. I, for one, will never criticise the Government for having taken the decision to float the exchange rate. It was the right decision and the present troubles the Government has are not a result of having made that decision. Rather, they are the result of the failure to understand the implications of what it was doing when it floated the exchange rate.

I yield to no one in my view that the problem the Government now has is that it has embraced a deregulated financial environment and that is now hitting hard against a rigid domestic wage structure. It leaves the Government unable to respond flexibly to changes in the exchange rate. The reason why the rest of the world is writing down our dollar, the reason why the rest of the world does not believe the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the reason why the Treasurer failed in his mission to New York and London a couple of weeks ago is that the rest of the world does not believe that this Government and this economy have effectively responded to the changes brought about by the devaluation of the dollar that occurred earlier this year. Because of that, the Government is left floundering with no policy instrument other than the rather brutal one of driving up interest rates to the highest levels that Australia has experienced for more than 50 years.

Members of the Government can guffaw and carry on at Question Time and they can go around the corridors of this building pretending that in some way they have weathered the crisis that our broken dollar has produced, but out there in middle Australia there is hurt being felt by people as a result of the Government's policy, the like of which they have not experienced in many years. If the Government imagines that this is a political or economic crisis that it can brush aside, that this is a crisis that will be around for only a couple of weeks, that it can laugh and clown its way through it and reel off all the rhetoric and all the slogans, then it is sadly mistaken. People remember what this Government has promised. I have just come back from Adelaide-what an appropriate place to be in today. That reminds all of us of a speech that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made in Adelaide almost a year ago-on 20 November 1984-when he was addressing a business lunch during the election campaign, a bare 10 days before the last Federal election. This is what the Prime Minister said:

Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from the successful policies of the last 20 months. We have ploughed the fields and sown the seeds and in the very near future we will harvest the crop.

Those were his words on 20 November 1984. That was the Prime Minister living out the lie for all he was worth 10 days before an election. That promise, that expectation which people bought, has been revealed as broken and as irrelevant as that infamous promise he made in 1983 in terms that even the Opposition could understand that under him there would be no capital gains tax. Having promised those interest rate reductions in November 1984, the Prime Minister went on to renew that promise in March and April of this year. So indeed did the Treasurer. Both of them, as late as March and April this year, were telling us that interest rates were going to fall. The poor old Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has been so left out of the changed game plan of the Government that he was promising lower interest rates up to two or three weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —And so was the Minister for Primary Industry.

—Yes, so was the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). He was promising interest rate reductions a couple of weeks after the last Budget. But we all know that, far from reaping the harvest of lower interest rates, this Prime Minister and this Treasurer have given us the highest interest rates we have experienced in 50 years since the years of the Great Depression. All the guffawing under the sun will not alter that basic reality. I can say to all those smug, complacent marginal seat holders in the Government that if they imagine they are out of the political woods on interest rates, if they imagine that they can smugly repair to their electorates with some half truths and propaganda handed to them by the Prime Minister and Treasurer as to the reality of the situation, they are sadly mistaken. The people they will go home to will say: `What about Bob's promise? He promised us lower interest rates'. In the last year the prime rate has gone up by 5 1/2 per cent and the small business rate by 4 per cent, the Bankcard rate is now 21 per cent, and the home savings loan rate has gone up by two per cent. People are paying $75 a month extra, and the middle Australian who wants to get a loan for the first time has to pay rates of up to 17 and 18 per cent. That is the harvest Mr Hawke has given us. That is the Keating-Hawke scoreboard. That is what the world's greatest Treasurer has given us. He has given us the world's worst interest rates, the world's weakest dollar, the biggest spending of any peacetime Australian Government, the highest tax levels and, despite the promise of the Prime Minister in 1983, he has also given us a new capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the scoreboard of Hawke and Keating. I say to members of the Government that if they imagine that this is just a passing phase, that somehow or other with a floating exchange rate if one closes one's eyes and hangs on long enough all the problems will go away, they are sadly mistaken. All those problems will not go away. I would like to know what the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) will say to the home buyers and small business people of Chisholm, who come along today and say: `What about the Prime Minister's promise on interest rates?'. I wonder what the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) will say. I know Barton like the back of my hand, and I can tell the House that mortgagees in Barton will not be very happy with their member of parliament. I reckon that if another poll were taken in Gallipoli Street, South Hurstville-where a poll is always taken before election day-it would be found that all the mortgagees there would be extremely worried. Therefore, it would be wrong for members of the Government to think they are out of the crisis on interest rates, or that somehow or other they can ride out that storm. It will be around for month after month, and month after month they will have to explain why the Government has not taken on its power brokers in the Australian Council of Trade Unions and said to them: `Look, the renegotiated accord was too generous. We have had to force up interest rates beyond reasonable limits'. Instead, what has the Government decided to do? The Government has played middle Australia for a mug and said: `We do not care how high your interest rates get. We are not willing to renegotiate the accord. The last thing we will do is to take on the ACTU'.

The reason the Treasurer had no option but to let interest rates go up further is that he is unwilling to do anything about the wages policy of the Government, because this country is locked into an inflexible wage fixation system which is totally incompatible with the floating exchange rate and a deregulated financial system. I know that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer stubbornly respond and say that a centralised wage fixation system is the only thing that will operate in Australia, but one cannot live in an environment where financial deregulation and a floating exchange rate rule the roost and one has a rigid centralised wage fixation system. If Government members doubt my words on that, I ask them to look at what has happened to the Australian dollar over the past 12 months. We had a massive devaluation at the beginning of the year and the trade-weighted index is at its lowest level ever. Our currency has fallen massively against the currencies of all our major trading partners. Measured in competitive terms, our position against our major trading partners is weaker than it has ever been. If that does not say something for the incompatability of a floating exchange rate and a centralised rigid wage fixation system, nothing does. The Government can pretend and put its head in the sand or like King Canute, hold its hand against the tide, but it cannot deny the reality of the judgments that have been made about it.

In Question Time today, when we asked how long the effect of the J curve would take-in other words, how long we will have to wait for the effects of devaluation to work-the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) could not answer. The fact is that the devaluation will not necessarily turn around our competitive position. It will not have quite the boost to local manufacturers and exports that the Government would hope. The reason for that is that we have not effectively utilised the benefits of the devaluation that occurred earlier this year.

When that devaluation occurred the Treasurer quite correctly said, and I agreed with him, that it gave to Australian industry a great opportunity to grab hold of its restored competitiveness and to improve its competitive position, but there was one condition to that. It was that there should be an effective discounting of wages for the full effects of the devaluation. Anybody who has studied what has happened knows quite well that that discounting simply did not take place. That was the first question the Opposition asked the Government in this House after the 1984 election. The Prime Minister commenced to back and fill then and he has gone on backing and filling about it for the last nine months.

The reason our dollar is in such a parlous condition at the moment is that the rest of the world simply is not convinced. The Treasurer went to New York to talk up the dollar and to reassure everybody. He made a speech and as soon as he had made the speech the dollar fell by another 5 per cent. Not content with that, he went on to London and, like the mug he was, he made the same speech again; so the dollar fell by another 4 or 5 per cent. The great Keating legacy, the great Keating endowment, from that overseas trip was a devalued dollar the like of which we have not seen before. Of course, the Labor Party can bask in its imagination that somehow or other a falling dollar and all the esoteric ins and outs of a floating exchange rate do not really mean anything in the Australian community. Maybe it does not, but the implications of not responding effectively to a floating exchange rate are absolutely lethal in political and economic terms for middle Australia.

I say to the Government that unless it is prepared to get its act together in properly responding to our floating exchange rate and puts in place a wages policy that enables this country to be competititve and pays people for productivity, profitability and output-not according to some outdated notion that everybody has to be paid the same whether they are performing or not-it will find over the coming months, to its cost, that the burden of high interest rates will drive its marginal seat holders out of office as surely as the fall in the dollar has driven up interest rates to levels that are now hurting literally hundreds of thousands of middle class families throughout Australia. I say to the Government, in all of its smugness of the past few days, that it should remember that out there middle Australia does not like it one bit.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

It is a record that makes the Opposition squirm, and that is why we find that the Leader of the Opposition has scurried out of the House and hurried away. I will go through the list because it bears repeating.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am getting a lot of very good help from them and I appreciate it very much. I want to go into detail on some of the statistics that I have briefly outlined. Real domestic product is growing strongly. A growth of 4.5 per cent is expected in 1985-86 after a 5 per cent growth in the previous two years. Non-farm domestic product is expected to rise by 5 per cent in the second half of 1984-85. There has been a particularly strong period of growth in the labour market since April 1983. We have mentioned a figure of 460,000 jobs which is expected to rise to 500,000. We have almost reached that half a million figure, but we are not going to stop there. We have a target of 150,000 for this financial year.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members will understand that I am particularly interested in talking about housing results. We have a very good Minister for Housing and Construction at the present time and, if I may so with my usual modesty, we had a reasonable one previously as well. The buoyant state of the housing sector reflects very well on this Government. A continuing strong supply of finance, the Government's housing policies, including the first home owners scheme, and the improvement in general economic conditions are all benefiting the housing market generally. I would like to point out the statistics for housing finance. We are hearing a lot about the increase in interest rates. It is so that in order to dampen down some of the overheating that is going on at the moment there are problems with interest rates. That is not the only reason. Another factor is that we do not live on an island as far as the economy of the rest of the world is concerned. Australia may be an island as far as its land mass is concerned, but, as far as the world economy is concerned, we cannnot isolate ourselves from it. As I know so well from representing this country and the Government at the recent meetings in Seoul of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, what has been happening to interest rates here is very much a reflection of the world level of interest rates. It is time some of the honourable members opposite educated themselves by reading, for instance, the Economist and realised what has happened to the real rate of interest not only in the United States of America but also in the United Kingdom and other countries of Europe. I repeat: We cannot isolate ourselves from the rest of the world and the high levels of interest are very much to do with the levels elsewhere.

That has not in any way adversely affected the level of housing finance. We have only to look at how it collapsed under the previous coalition. In 1979-80, $7,018m was spent on housing finance. Unfortunately my time has been curtailed by the irresponsible actions of the Whip on the other side, but before I finish I want to say that it was irresponsible of the Leader of the Opposition to bring this proposition to this House as a matter of public importance. We have shown that in no way is there a deteriorating state in our economy. In no way is there any chance that there will not be continuing growth in our economy. In no way are the policies that are in place now not going to mean that the fundamentals of our economy will continue to be good.
